{{Redirect|DBCP|the database connection pool implementation|Apache Commons}} {{chembox | Watchedfields = changed | verifiedrevid = 477203298 | ImageFile = 1,2-Dibrom-3-chlorpropan Grundstruktur V1-Seite001.svg | ImageFile1 = 1,2-Dibromo-3-chloropropane3d.png | IUPACName = 1,2-Dibromo-3-chloropropane | OtherNames = 1,2-Dibromo-3-chloropropane
Dibromochloropropane |Section1={{Chembox Identifiers | Abbreviations = DBCP | ChemSpiderID_Ref = {{chemspidercite|correct|chemspider}} | ChemSpiderID = 7008 | InChIKey = WBEJYOJJBDISQU-UHFFFAOYAN | StdInChI_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChI = 1S/C3H5Br2Cl/c4-1-3(5)2-6/h3H,1-2H2 | StdInChIKey_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChIKey = WBEJYOJJBDISQU-UHFFFAOYSA-N | CASNo_Ref = {{cascite|correct|CAS}} | CASNo = 96-12-8 | EINECS = | PubChem = 7280 | UNII_Ref = {{fdacite|correct|FDA}} | UNII = 96K0FD4803 | SMILES = BrC(CBr)CCl | InChI = 1/C3H5Br2Cl/c4-1-3(5)2-6/h3H,1-2H2 | RTECS = | MeSHName = | ChEBI_Ref = {{ebicite|correct|EBI}} | ChEBI = | KEGG_Ref = {{keggcite|correct|kegg}} | KEGG = C14336 }} |Section2={{Chembox Properties | C=3 | H=5 | Br=2 | Cl=1 | MolarMass = 236.33 g/mol | Appearance = Dense yellow or amber liquid | Odor = pungent odor at high concentrations | Density = 2.05 g/mL | MeltingPtC = 6.1 | BoilingPtC = 195.5 | Solubility = 0.1% | SolubleOther = | Solvent = | pKa = | pKb = | IsoelectricPt = | SpecRotation = | RefractIndex = | Viscosity = | VaporPressure = 0.8 mmHg (20°C) }} |Section3={{Chembox Structure | CrystalStruct = | Coordination = | MolShape = | Dipole = }} |Section4={{Chembox Thermochemistry | DeltaHf = | DeltaHc = | Entropy = | HeatCapacity = }} |Section5={{Chembox Pharmacology | Bioavail = | Metabolism = | HalfLife = | Excretion = | Pregnancy_category = | AdminRoutes = }} |Section6={{Chembox Explosive | ShockSens = | FrictionSens = | DetonationV = | REFactor = }} |Section7={{Chembox Hazards | ExternalSDS = | MainHazards = carcinogen | NFPA-H = 2 | NFPA-F = 1 | NFPA-R = 1 | NFPA-S = | GHSPictograms = {{GHSp|GHS06}}{{GHSp|GHS08}} | HPhrases = {{GHSp|H301}} - {{GHSp|H340}} - {{GHSp|H350}} - {{GHSp|H360}} - {{GHSp|H373}} - {{GHSp|H412}}{{Sigma-Aldrich|Aldrich|id=676713|name=1,2-Dibromo-3-chloropropane|accessdate=2013-07-20}} | PPhrases = {{GHSp|P201}} - {{GHSp|P273}} - {{GHSp|P301+P310}} - {{GHSp|P308+P313}} | FlashPtC = 76.7 | AutoignitionPtC = | ExploLimits = | PEL = TWA 0.001 ppm {{PGCH|0184}} | IDLH = Ca, N.D. | REL = Ca }} |Section8={{Chembox Related | OtherAnions = | OtherCations = | OtherFunction = | OtherFunction_label = | OtherCompounds = }} }} '''1,2-Dibromo-3-chloropropane''', ('''dibromochloropropane''') better known as '''DBCP''', is the active ingredient in the [[nematicide]] '''Nemagon''', also known as Fumazone. It is a soil [[fumigant]] formerly used in American [[agriculture]]. In mammals it causes male sterility at high levels of exposure. After discovery of its deleterious health effects on humans, the compound was banned from use in 1979 by the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA).[http://www.epa.gov/ttn/atw/hlthef/dibromo-.html Hazard Summary]. - [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]]. - EPA.gov. The continuing presence of the chemical as a [[contaminant]] in [[ground water]] remains a problem for many communities for years after end of use. == Stereoisomerism == {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- class="hintergrundfarbe6" ! colspan="2"| 1,2-Dibrom-3-chlorpropane
(2 stereoisomers) |- | [[File:(R)-1,2-Dibrom-3-chlorpropan V2-Seite001.svg|200px|''(R)''-1,2-Dibrom-3-chlorpropan]]
(''R'')-configuration | [[File:(S)-1,2-Dibrom-3-chlorpropan V2-Seite001.svg|200px|''(S)''-1,2-Dibrom-3-chlorpropan]]
(''S'')-configuration |} == Uses == * Until 1977, DBCP was used as a soil [[fumigant]] and [[nematocide]] on over 40 different crops in the United States. It fights pests that attack the roots of fruit trees and boosts the weight of harvests by 20 percent.Spano, John. - "Dole Must Pay $2.5 Million in Punitive Damages". - ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''. - November 15, 2007. From 1977 to 1979, EPA suspended registration for all DBCP-containing products except for use on pineapples in [[Hawaii]]. In 1985, EPA issued an intent to cancel all registrations for DBCP, including use on [[pineapple]]s. Subsequently, the use of existing stocks of DBCP was prohibited. * DBCP is used as an intermediate in the [[synthesis of organic chemicals]]. == Sources and potential exposure == * Human exposure to DBCP could result from the ingestion of contaminated [[drinking water]] and food. * Human exposure could also result from inhalation and / or skin contact with the product. * In the past, release of DBCP to the environment occurred primarily from its fumigant and nematocide uses; because of the cancellation of all DBCP uses, environmental exposure is expected to decline with time. == Examples of persistence == DBCP residues have persisted in [[soil contamination|contaminated soil]] and groundwater long after applications have ceased. For example, in agricultural areas around [[Turlock, California|Turlock]] in the [[California Central Valley|Central Valley]] of California, DBCP was applied to crops in the 1970s. As late as 1989, DBCP persistence was reported in groundwater that was previously used for beneficial purposes, and numerous nearby [[water well|wells]] had to be shut down at that time."Environmental Screening Analysis, Tully Road Properties, Turlock, California". - Earth Metrics Incorporated. - Report 7826, San Mateo, California. - March, 1989 == Lawsuits == Workers at the [[Dow Chemical]] plant producing DBCP were made [[Infertility|sterile]] by exposure to DBCP. These male reproductive effects were consistent with animal experiments showing that DBCP sterilizes rabbits. One contract worker at the production plant successfully sued the company. Most workers remained with the company and in a company sponsored medical program until the facility was sold in 1987. At that time, some of the workers did file suit against the company. However, the suit was denied due to [[statute of limitations]] issues. Most domestic uses of the chemical were banned in 1977. Amid growing concerns over DBCP's effects on male workers, Dow ceased production and reclaimed DBCP that had been shipped to its users. However, despite warnings from Dow about its health effects, the [[Dole Food Company]], which was using the chemical on its [[banana]] [[plantation]]s in [[Latin America]], threatened to sue Dow if it stopped DBCP shipments. Dow then shipped half a million gallons of DBCP to Dole, much of it reclaimed from other users. Plantation workers who became sterile or were stricken with other maladies subsequently sued Dow and Dole in Nicaraguan courts, alleging that their ailments were caused by DBCP exposure. Under a special law that was passed specifically for DBCP litigation, the Nicaraguan courts ruled in favor of the plaintiffs and awarded them over US$600 million in damages. When plaintiff lawyers tried to enforce one of those judgments in the United States, the U.S. District Court in Florida held that "the credible and unrefuted medical testimony in this case is that it is factually impossible for what is represented in the Judgment to have occurred," and that due process "do[es] not permit awarding damages in the face of clear scientific evidence of the absence of causation," or, as in this case, "with proof that [the defendants] are not at fault."[http://www.rttnews.com/1104848/u-s-court-refuses-to-enforce-nicaragua-judgment-against-dole-food-update.aspx "U.S. Court Refuses To Enforce Nicaragua Judgment Against Dole Food - Update"]. - ''[[rttnews.com]]''. - October 26, 2009 A group of workers then filed lawsuits in the United States, and on November 5, 2007, a Los Angeles jury awarded them US$3.2 million.Spano, John. - [http://www.latimes.com/news/printedition/california/la-me-dole6nov06,1,2105565.story "Dole must pay farmworkers $3.2 million"]. - ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''. - November 6, 2007. On July 15, 2010, that judgment was thrown out after the Court presiding over the case found that the claims were part of "a massive fraud perpetrated on the court".[http://www.foxnews.com/us/2010/07/15/california-judge-dismisses-m-jury-award-dole-food-banana-workers-case/ "California judge dismisses $2.3M jury award against Dole Food Co. in banana workers case"]. - ''[[FoxNews.com]]''. - July 15, 2010 On April 23, 2009, a Los Angeles judge also threw out two similar cases against Dole and Dow Chemical due to fraud and extortion by lawyers in Nicaragua recruiting fraudulent plaintiffs to make claims against the company.Hallman, Ben. - [http://www.law.com/jsp/article.jsp?id=1202430211082&rss=newswire "Finding Plaintiffs Lawyers Committed Fraud, Judge Dismisses Tort Cases Against Dole and Dow Chemical"]. - ''[[The American Lawyer]]''. - April 27, 2009. The ruling casts doubt on US$2 [[1,000,000,000 (number)|billion]] in judgments in similar lawsuits.Keating, Gina. - [https://www.forbes.com/feeds/reuters/2009/04/24/2009-04-24T052809Z_01_N21503396_RTRIDST_0_BANANAS-UPDATE-2.html "Judge throws out Dole "bananeros" cases, citing fraud"]. - ''[[Forbes]]''. - April 24, 2009. Workers in [[Côte d'Ivoire]], using the [[Alien Tort Claims Act]], and claiming sterility, crimes against humanity, and [[genocide]], sued (in ''Abagninin v. AMVAC Chemical Corp.'' [No. 07-56326]), these manufacturers of DBCP: Amvac Chemical, [[Dow Chemical]], [[Shell Oil Company]], as well as [[Dole Food Company]], who used it on overseas crops, but never used it in Côte d'Ivoire. The [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit]] ruled against the workers in September 2008, stating that the plaintiffs did not show that the defendants had "specific intent" to intend harm against the workers and the citizens of the country. To be found guilty of genocide the defendant must have knowingly set out to commit the offense.[http://www.ca9.uscourts.gov/ca9/newopinions.nsf/40AB16BDDF8C33D9882574CD007E8677/$file/0756326.pdf?openelement ''Abagninin v. AMVAC Chemical Corp.'']. - [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit]]. - September 24, 2008. - (Adobe Acrobat *.PDF document).Williams, Carol J. - "Appeals Court Rules Against Ivory Coast Farm Workers". - ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''. - September 24, 2008. == Safety == DBCP causes a dramatic decrease in male fertility, ranging from [[oligospermia]] (low sperm count) to [[azoospermia]] (lack of sperm).{{Cite journal|title = DDT exposure, work in agriculture, and time to pregnancy among farmworkers in California|journal = Journal of Occupational and Environmental Medicine|date = Dec 2008|issn = 1536-5948|pmc = 2684791|pmid = 19092487|pages = 1335–1342|volume = 50|issue = 12|doi = 10.1097/JOM.0b013e31818f684d|first = Kim G.|last = Harley|first2 = Amy R.|last2 = Marks|first3 = Asa|last3 = Bradman|first4 = Dana B.|last4 = Barr|first5 = Brenda|last5 = Eskenazi}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.commondreams.org/archive/2007/05/27/1487/ Article about Nemagon use in Nicaragua] * [http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/tfacts36.html ATSDR ToxFAQs] * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/ipcsneng/neng0002.html International Chemical Safety Card] * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/npg/npgd0184.html CDC - NIOSH Pocket Guide to Chemical Hazards] {{DEFAULTSORT:Dibromo-3-Chloropropane, 1,2-}} [[Category:Nematicides]] [[Category:Fumigants]] [[Category:Occupational safety and health]] [[Category:Agriculture in California]] [[Category:Central Valley (California)]] [[Category:Environmental effects of pesticides]] [[Category:IARC Group 2B carcinogens]] [[Category:Organobromides]] [[Category:Organochlorides]] [[Category:Testicular toxicants]]

revision.text:
{{See also|2009 flu pandemic by country|2009 flu pandemic tables}} {{pp-move-indef}} {{Main article|2009 flu pandemic}} {{Very long|date=May 2011}} [[File:H1N1 map by confirmed community outbreaks.svg|400px|thumb|Community outbreaks, June 2009]] [[File:H1N1 June 3 2009 USA.svg|thumb|400px|Confirmed cases by [[U.S. state]], June 3, 2009]]
This article covers the chronology of the 2009 novel influenza A ([[H1N1]]) pandemic.<ref name="cdc.gov">{{cite web |url=https://www.cdc.gov/h1n1flu/ |title=CDC 2009 H1N1 Flu |author=<!--not specified--> |date=11 August 2010 |website=cdc.gov |publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] |accessdate=20 June 2013 }}</ref> Flag icons denote the first announcements of confirmed cases by the respective nation-states, their first deaths (and other major events such as their first intergenerational cases, cases of [[zoonosis]], and the start of national vaccination campaigns), and relevant sessions and announcements of the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO), the [[European Union]] (and its agency the [[European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control]]), and the U.S. [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|Centers for Disease Control]] (CDC).
Unless otherwise noted, references to terms like S-OIV, H1N1 and such, all refer to this new A(H1N1) strain and not to sundry other strains of H1N1 which are endemic in humans, birds and pigs.
{{TOC limit|limit=3}}
==Timeline== Take note that the date of the first confirmations of the disease or any event in a country may be before or after the date of the events in local time because of the [[International Dateline]].
[[File:CDC MMWR M8d0430a2f.png|260px|thumb|Probable and confirmed Mexican cases by date of illness onset, March 15 – April 26. —CDC]]
===March 2009===
{{flagicon|Mexico}} '''Mexico''' In [[La Gloria, Veracruz]] 60% of the town's population is sickened by a [[Acute respiratory infection|respiratory illness]] of unknown provenance. The government of Mexico believes it to be caused by [[H3N2]] influenza, though at least one patient in La Gloria tested positive for A/H1N1. Two babies died in the outbreak but both were buried without testing.<ref name='Guardian Tuckman 04-27-09'>{{cite news|first=Jo|last=Tuckman|title=Four-year-old could hold key in search for source of swine flu outbreak|date=2009-04-27|work=[[The Guardian]]|url =https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/apr/27/swine-flu-search-outbreak-source | location=London| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
====March 7==== {{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' In the ninth week of its routine influenza surveillance, the CDC reports on FluView that thirty-five states have reported widespread influenza activity, and 14 states have reported regional activity, but that although the rate of activity was high, that the proportion of deaths attributed to pneumonia and influenza (P&I) was below the epidemic threshold.<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/weeklyarchives2008-2009/weekly09.htm CDC - Influenza (Flu)|Weekly Report: Influenza Summary Update Week 09, 2008-2009 Season]. Cdc.gov</ref>
====March 14==== {{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' The CDC reports on the 10th week of FluView that thirty states reported widespread influenza activity and 18 states reported regional activity.<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/weeklyarchives2008-2009/weekly10.htm CDC - Influenza (Flu)|Weekly Report: Influenza Summary Update Week 10, 2008-2009 Season]. Cdc.gov</ref>
====March 17==== {{flagicon|Mexico}} '''Mexico''' Earliest known onset of a case that is later to be confirmed as Swine-Origin Influenza A (H1N1) Virus Infection.<ref name="MMWR-58d0430a2">{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm58d0430a2.htm |title=Outbreak of Swine-Origin Influenza A (H1N1) Virus Infection --- Mexico, March--April 2009 |date=2009-04-30 |publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) |work=[[Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhPR679t?url=http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm58d0430a2.htm |archivedate=2009-09-11 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=ProjectDisaster ' Blog Archive ' Mexico & H1N1 |url=http://projectdisaster.com/?p=13947 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhPRWY7f?url=http://projectdisaster.com/?p=13947 |archivedate=2009-09-11 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
====March 21==== {{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' CDC FluView, Week 11: Widespread influenza activity in twenty-four states; regional activity in 19. Influenza activity continues to decrease.<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/weeklyarchives2008-2009/weekly11.htm CDC - Influenza (Flu)|Weekly Report: Influenza Summary Update Week 11, 2008-2009 Season]. Cdc.gov</ref>
====March 28==== [[File:H1N1 illness onset dates - United States.svg|260px|thumb|Confirmed USA cases with known dates of illness onset (April 27, 2009). —CDC]]
{{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' Earliest known onset of a USA case later confirmed as swine flu, that of a nine-year-old girl residing in [[Imperial County, California]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/04/21/AR2009042103694.html |title=New Strain of Swine Flu Investigated: Two Children in San Diego Area Had No Contact With Pigs |first=David |last=Brown |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=2009-04-22 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5gRa3URY4?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/04/21/AR2009042103694.html |archivedate=2009-05-01 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref name="MMWR5815a5">{{cite journal |url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5815a5.htm |title=Swine influenza A (H1N1) infection in two children --- Southern California, March--April 2009 |date=2009-04-21 |publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) |work=[[Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report]] |volume=58 (Dispatch) |issue=1–3 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jiAdcpUZ?url=http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5815a5.htm |archivedate=2009-09-11 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Thirteen states reported widespread influenza activity and 19 reported regional activity on the CDC's FluView, Week 12.<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/weeklyarchives2008-2009/weekly12.htm CDC - Influenza (Flu)|Weekly Report: Influenza Summary Update Week 12, 2008-2009 Season]. Cdc.gov</ref>
====March 30====
{{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' A sample is collected from a nine-year-old female patient which is later confirmed to contain the novel virus strain (genetically sequenced as A/California/05/2009(H1N1)).<ref name="NCBI-20090502-Flu">{{cite web|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genomes/FLU/SwineFlu.html |title=GenBank sequences from 2009 H1N1 influenza outbreak |date=2009-05-01 |work=Influenza Virus Resource |publisher=[[National Center for Biotechnology Information|NCBI]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5gSgGU4WL?url=http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genomes/FLU/SwineFlu.html |archivedate=2009-05-02 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nuccore/FJ966955 |title=Influenza A virus (A/California/05/2009(H1N1)) segment 1 polymerase PB2 (PB2) gene, complete cds |publisher=[[National Center for Biotechnology Information|NCBI]]| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' Onset of illness for a ten-year-old boy residing in [[San Diego County, California]]; his case is eventually the first to be confirmed as swine flu in the US.<ref name="MMWR5815a5" />
===April 2009===
====April 1====
{{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' A [[nasopharynx|nasopharyngeal]] swab is collected from a ten-year-old male patient in San Diego County, later confirmed as containing the novel virus and the first organism of that strain to be completely [[Full genome sequencing|sequenced]] (A/California/04/2009(H1N1)).<ref name="MMWR5815a5" /><ref name="NCBI-20090502-Flu" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nuccore/FJ966079 |title=Influenza A virus (A/California/04/2009(H1N1)) segment 1 polymerase PB2 (PB2) gene, complete cds |publisher=[[National Center for Biotechnology Information|NCBI]] | accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
====April 2====
{{flagicon|Mexico}} '''Mexico''' In [[La Gloria, Veracruz]], a four-year-old boy falls ill at the end of the outbreak. Only his sample, which was eventually sent abroad, tested positive for A(H1N1). Veracruz officials state that there were no plans to exhume the bodies of two infants who died in the outbreak.<ref name="Guardian Tuckman 04-27-09" />
====April 4==== {{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' CDC FluView, Week 13: Widespread influenza activity in four states, regional activity in 18.<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/weeklyarchives2008-2009/weekly13.htm CDC - Influenza (Flu)|Weekly Report: Influenza Summary Update Week 12, 2008-2009 Season]. Cdc.gov</ref>
====April 5==== {{flagicon|EU}} '''European Union''' The media monitoring website MedISys reports on a Mexican article about the epidemiological alert.<ref name="MED-20090405-Jrc">{{cite news |url=http://medusa.jrc.it/medisys/dynamic?language=all&page=1&edition=searchresults&option=&category=&articleType=all&foralert=Diarrhoea&forsource=&duplicates=false&querytype=simple&atLeast=Alerta+epidemiol%F3gica+en+Perote+por+brote+de+males+respiratorios |title=First article on novel influenza reported by MedISys |last=MedISys |first=EC |date=2008-04-05 |publisher=EC |accessdate=2 August 2010 }}. [https://www.webcitation.org/5jhQjJqow?url=http://medusa.jrc.it/medisys/dynamic?language=all&page=1&edition=searchresults&option=&category=&articleType=all&foralert=Diarrhoea&forsource=&duplicates=false&querytype=simple&atLeast=Alerta+epidemiol%EF%BF%BDgica+en+Perote+por+brote+de+males+respiratorios Archived] 2009-09-10.</ref><ref name="MED-20090405-Jor">{{cite news|url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2009/04/05/index.php?section=estados&article=025n1est&partner=rss|title=Alerta epidemiológica en Perote por brote de males respiratorios|last=Jornada|first=La|date=2008-04-05|publisher=LaJornada| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}} </ref>
====April 6====
{{flagicon|Mexico}} '''Mexico''' Public health authorities begin investigating unusual cases of [[pneumonia]].<ref name="WP-20090430-Brown">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/04/29/AR2009042904911.html |title=Reporting Health Threats: System Set Up After SARS Epidemic Was Slow to Alert Global Authorities |last=Brown |first=David |date=2009-04-30 |work=[[The Washington Post]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5gRBqf7So?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/04/29/AR2009042904911.html |archivedate=2009-05-01 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> 400 people had reportedly sought treatment for pneumonia/[[influenza-like illness]] (ILI) in La Gloria the preceding week.<ref name="WP-20090430-Brown" />
{{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' Biosurveillance firm [[Veratect Corporation|Veratect]] reports the unusual respiratory illness in Mexico.<ref name="McC-20090430-Blu">{{cite news|url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2009/04/30/67283/company-warned-officials-of-flu.html|title=Company warned officials of flu 18 days before alert was issued|last=Blumenthal|first=Les|date=2009-05-01|publisher=McClatchy Newspapers| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://veratect.com/media/042609_release.pdf |format=PDF |title=Veratect the Company to First Sound Alarm on Swine Influenza Makes Data on the Spread of this Disease Public |date=2009-04-27 |work=Corporate press release |publisher=Veratect Inc | accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> Veratect publishes the alert "La Gloria: 'Strange' Respiratory Affects 60% of Local Population; Three Pediatric Deaths May be Associated with the Outbreak."<ref name="WP-20090430-Brown" /><ref name="McC-20090430-Blu" />
====April 11==== {{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' CDC FluView, Week 14: Widespread influenza activity in one state; regional activity in 14.<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/weeklyarchives2008-2009/weekly14.htm CDC - Influenza (Flu)|Weekly Report: Influenza Summary Update Week 12, 2008-2009 Season]. Cdc.gov</ref>
====April 12==== {{flagicon|Mexico}} '''Mexico''' The [[General Directorate of Epidemiology]] (DGE) reports the outbreak of an ILI in a small community in Veracruz to the '''[[Pan American Health Organization]]''' ('''PAHO'''), which is the Regional Office of the '''[[World Health Organization]]''' ('''WHO''').<ref name="MMWR-58d0430a2" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Outbreak of Swine-Origin Influenza A (H1N1) Virus Infection --- Mexico, March--April 2009 |url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm58d0430a2.htm |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhPR679t?url=http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm58d0430a2.htm |archivedate=2009-09-11 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Furthermore, a 39-year-old woman dies of severe [[viral pneumonia]] in the city of [[San Luis Potosí, San Luis Potosí|San Luis Potosí]]; this is later believed to be the earliest known fatality related to the outbreak.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/04/25/AR2009042501335.html |title=U.S. Slow to Learn of Mexico Flu: Canadian Officials Knew of Rare Strain Before Americans Did |last=Brown |first=David |date=2009-04-26 |work=[[The Washington Post]] |quote=The earliest case found in Mexico was a 39-year-old woman who died April 12 of severe viral pneumonia in San Luis Potosi, a city of about 700,000 in central Mexico. "That attracted the attention of the epidemiologist there," said Mauricio Hernández, deputy minister for disease prevention and health promotion in Mexico's Federal Department of Health | accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
====April 13====
{{flagicon|Mexico}} '''Mexico''' First death in [[Oaxaca]] due to what would later be identified as swine flu.<ref>{{cite news|last=Orsi |first=Peter |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gfYcVCw5PiKbk5yaX7JaF9NqhPygD97R0QOO0 |title=Mexico says suspected swine flu deaths now at 149 |agency=Associated Press |work=Google News |date=2009-04-27 |archivedate=2009-04-28 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5gNf8rqeS?url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gfYcVCw5PiKbk5yaX7JaF9NqhPygD97R0QOO0 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' The U.S. [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|Centers for Disease Control]] (CDC) is advised of a ten-year-old boy with a respiratory illness in San Diego County, California. Test results revealed an Influenza A virus but were negative for standard human strains. The San Diego County [[Health department#Sub-national|Health Department]] is notified.<ref name="MMWR5815a5" />
====April 14==== {{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' The CDC receives its first sample from California (from the ten-year-old boy in San Diego County), and identifies the virus as a strain of swine influenza A(H1N1).<ref name="MMWR5815a5" />
====April 16====
{{flagicon|Mexico}} '''Mexico''' Authorities notify the '''PAHO''' of the [[atypical pneumonia]].<ref name="WP-20090430-Brown" />
{{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' Veratect publishes the alert "Atypical Pneumonia Cases Reported at Hospital" regarding the Oaxaca cases.<ref name="WP-20090430-Brown" /><ref name="McC-20090430-Blu" />
====April 17====
{{flagicon|Mexico}} '''Mexico''' A case of atypical pneumonia in Oaxaca prompts enhanced national surveillance. A field investigation is started.<ref name="MMWR-58d0430a2" /> Mexico contacts '''Canada''' to request more specialized testing.<ref name="PHAC-20090424-Adv">{{cite web|url=http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/alert-alerte/h1n1/sn_swine-eng.php?option=print |title=Human Swine Influenza Outbreak. Message from the Minister of Health and the Chief Public Health Officer on Human Swine Flu |date=2009-04-24 |work=Advisories |publisher=[[Public Health Agency of Canada]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5gSWgrBKO?url=http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/alert-alerte/h1n1/sn_swine-eng.php |archivedate=2009-05-02 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' The CDC receives a second sample from Southern California (taken from the nine-year-old girl in Imperial County), and again identifies the virus as a strain of swine influenza A(H1N1). The [[California Department of Public Health]] is notified.<ref name="MMWR5815a5" />
====April 18==== {{flagicon|Mexico}} '''Mexico''' Mexico sends 14 mucus samples to the CDC and dispatches health teams hospitals to look for patients showing severe influenza- or pneumonia-like symptoms.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://komonews.com/news/local/us-mexico-battle-deadly-flu-outbreak-11-21-2015 |title=U.S., Mexico battle deadly flu outbreak |last=Stevenson |first=Mark |agency=[[Associated Press|AP]] |date=2009-04-26 |work=KomoNews.com |publisher=Fisher Communications, Inc. | accessdate= 22 July 2016 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' CDC FluView, Week 15: "Nine states reported regional activity; 17 states reported local influenza activity; the District of Columbia and 22 states reported sporadic influenza activity; and two states reported no influenza activity. Seven human infections with swine influenza A (H1N1) virus have been confirmed." This is the first mention of A(H1N1) in FluView.<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/weeklyarchives2008-2009/weekly15.htm CDC - Influenza (Flu)|Weekly Report: Influenza Summary Update Week 15, 2008-2009 Season]. Cdc.gov</ref>
====April 20====
{{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' Veratect advises the CDC of the Mexican events.<ref name="WP-20090430-Brown" /><ref name="McC-20090430-Blu" /> The CDC is already investigating the California and [[Texas]] cases.<ref name="WP-20090430-Brown" /><ref name="McC-20090430-Blu" /><ref name="AP-20090430-Stobbe">{{cite news |title=Officials alert doctors after 2 California children infected with unusual swine flu |last=Stobbe |first=Mike |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=2009-04-21 |url=http://www.startribune.com/lifestyle/health/43357097.html |work=[[Star Tribune]] |accessdate=2010-08-02 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090430115903/http://www.startribune.com/lifestyle/health/43357097.html |archivedate=2009-04-30 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
====April 21====
{{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' The CDC alerts physicians to a similar novel strain of swine influenza A(H1N1) in two cases from Southern California in an [[Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report]] Early Release on its website.<ref name="autogenerated2">[https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5815a5.htm Swine Influenza A (H1N1) Infection in Two Children - Southern California, March-April 2009]. Cdc.gov</ref> Local investigations, including investigations in Texas, are already underway, and overall surveillance is enhanced.<ref name="MMWR5815a5" /><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Novel Swine-Origin Influenza A (H1N1) Virus Investigation Team |last2=Dawood |first2=FS |last3=Jain |first3=S |last4=Finelli |first4=L |last5=Shaw |first5=MW |last6=Lindstrom |first6=S |last7=Garten |first7=RJ |last8=Gubareva |first8=LV |last9=Xu |first9=X |title=Emergence of a novel swine-origin influenza A (H1N1) virus in humans |journal=The New England Journal of Medicine |volume=360 |issue=25 |pages=2605–15 |year=2009 |pmid=19423869 |doi=10.1056/NEJMoa0903810}}</ref> [[Associated Press|The Associated Press]] covers the alert, the first mention of the A(H1N1) outbreak in English-language news media.<ref name="AP-20090430-Stobbe" /><ref> {{cite journal |vauthors=Brownstein JS, Freifeld CC, Madoff LC | title = Influenza A (H1N1) virus, 2009--online monitoring | journal = [[The New England Journal of Medicine]] | volume = 360 | issue = 21 | page = 2156 | date=May 2009 | pmid = 19423868 | doi = 10.1056/NEJMp0904012 | url = http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/full/NEJMp0904012 | accessdate = 2010-02-06 | pmc = 2922951 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100213154505/http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/full/NEJMp0904012| archivedate= 13 February 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="Fox-AP-20090421-Stobbe">{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/printer_friendly_wires/2009Apr21/0,4675,MEDSwineFlu,00.html |title=Swine flu cases in Calif. worry health officials |last=Stobbe |first=Mike |agency=[[Associated Press|AP]] |date=2009-04-21 |work=[[Fox News]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5gSuyWo6a?url=http://www.foxnews.com/printer_friendly_wires/2009Apr21/0,4675,MEDSwineFlu,00.html |archivedate=2009-05-02 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
====April 22====
{{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''' Canada receives the samples from Mexico for testing.<ref name="PHAC-20090424-Adv" />
====April 23====
{{flagicon|Mexico}} '''Mexico''' The [[Public Health Agency of Canada|Public Health Agency of '''Canada''']] confirms Mexico cases of swine-origin influenza A (H1N1) virus (S-OIV) infection.<ref name="MMWR-58d0430a2" /> Genetic sequence analysis reveals that the Mexican patients were infected with the same S-OIV strain detected in two California children.<ref name="MMWR-58d0430a2" /> The '''PAHO''' is informed that a cluster in Mexico of severe respiratory illnesses has been laboratory-confirmed as S-OIV infection.<ref name="MMWR-58d0430a2" />
====April 24====
{{flagicon|WHO}}The '''WHO''' issues its first Disease Outbreak Notice on the matter, confirming the infection of a number of people in Mexico and the United States by "Swine Influenza A/H1N1 viruses... not... previously detected in pigs or humans".<ref name="who_don_2009-04-24">{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_04_24/en/index.html |title=(Update 1) Influenza-Like Illness in the United States and Mexico |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] |date=2009-04-24 |accessdate=2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100628210557/http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_04_24/en/index.html |archivedate=28 June 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|Mexico}} '''Mexico''' The [[Secretary of Health (Mexico)|Minister of Health]] confirms the Mexican cases of human infection by swine influenza and states that it believes that some of these cases had resulted in death.<ref name="CDC-20090424-Brief" /> Health authorities implement public health measures for all airport passengers and the vaccination of health care workers with [[Flu season|seasonal]] [[influenza vaccine]].<ref name="MMWR-58d0430a2" />
[[File:Barack Obama being briefed on swine flu oubreak 4-29.jpg|thumb|250px| President Obama is briefed in the Situation Room about the H1N1 outbreak.]] {{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' The CDC tells a press conference that seven of the 14 Mexican samples contained the same virus strain as the known in California and Texas, and that indications suggested that containment in the USA was "not very likely".<ref name="CDC-20090424-Brief">{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/media/transcripts/2009/t090424.htm |title=CDC Briefing on Public Health Investigation of Human Cases of Swine Influenza (April 24, 2009) |date=2009-04-24 |work=Press Briefing Transcripts |publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) | accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> The novel strain had already been reported on the CDC's [[Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report]] website.<ref name="autogenerated2"/>
====April 25====
{{flagicon|WHO}} '''WHO''' Under the [[International Health Regulations]] (IHR), the Emergency Committee convenes for the first time since its establishment in 2007,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insidejustice.com/intl/2009/04/30/swine_flu_who_pheic/|title=Inside Justice - Swine Flu: Legal Obligations and Consequences When the World Health Organization Declares a "Public Health Emergency of International Concern"|website=www.insidejustice.com}}</ref> resulting in the [[WHO Director-General|'''WHO''' Director-General]] declaring a formal "public health emergency of international concern,"<ref name="WHO-20090425-Chan">{{cite news|url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/statements/2009/h1n1_20090425/en/index.html |title=Statement by WHO Director-General, Dr Margaret Chan (25 April 2009): Swine influenza |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] |date=2009-04-25 | accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_04_26/en/index.html |title=WHO | Swine flu illness in the United States and Mexico - update 2 |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] |date=2009-04-26 |accessdate=2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100822215512/http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_04_26/en/index.html |archivedate=22 August 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> ([[PHEIC]]),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/ihr/procedures/pheic/en/|title=WHO - IHR Procedures concerning public health emergencies of international concern (PHEIC)|website=www.who.int}}</ref> the first ever.
{{flagicon|WHO}}The '''PAHO''' [[Vaccination Week In The Americas|Vaccination Week In The '''Americas''']] starts.<ref name="PAHO-VW-2009">{{cite web|url=http://new.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=750&Itemid=1 |title=Vaccination Week In The Americas (2009 portal) |publisher=[[Pan American Health Organization]] |year=2009 |accessdate=2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100806204515/http://new.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=750&Itemid=1 |archivedate=6 August 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> The 2009 Week was planned to emphasize the vaccination of entire families, and health worker [[immunization]].<ref name="PAHO-VW-2009" />
{{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' First closure of an entire school district, the Schertz-Cibolo-Universal City Independent School District outside San Antonio, [[Texas]].<ref name=abramson2009>{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=103613643&ft=1&f=1004 |title=First Texas school district closure |last1=Abramson |first1=Larry |date=29 April 2009 |website= |publisher=[[NPR]] |accessdate=17 June 2013 }}</ref><ref name=TEA2009>{{cite web |url=http://ritter.tea.state.tx.us/swineflu/schclosings.html |title=List of Texas school district closures |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=1 May 2009 |publisher=[[Texas Education Agency]] |accessdate=10 June 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090502120215/http://ritter.tea.state.tx.us/swineflu/schclosings.html |archivedate=2 May 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
====April 27==== [[File:World Health Organisation regional offices.svg|thumb|400px|right|World Health Organization Regions {{legend|#78aae6|Africa; HQ: [[Brazzaville]], [[Republic of Congo|Congo]]}} {{legend|#7ae6ce|[[Pan American Health Organization|Americas]]; HQ: [[Washington, DC]], [[United States of America|USA]]}} {{legend|#9de678|Europe; HQ: [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]]}} {{legend|#e6e678|Eastern [[Mediterranean|Med.]]; HQ: [[Cairo]], [[Egypt]]}} {{legend|#e078e6|South East Asia; HQ: [[New Delhi]], [[India]]}} {{legend|#e67878|Western Pacific; HQ: [[Manila]], [[Philippines]]}}]]
[[File:Mexican Catholics at the Metropolitan Cathedral Swine Flu.jpg|thumb|350px|[[Mexico City Metropolitan Cathedral]]]]
{{flagicon|WHO}} '''WHO''' The Emergency Committee meets for the second time. The '''WHO''' Director-General issues a statement that containment of the outbreak is not feasible, and elevates the pandemic alert from Phase 3 to Phase 4.<ref name="WHO-20090427-Chan">{{cite web |url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/statements/2009/h1n1_20090427/en/index.html |title=Statement by WHO Director-General, Dr Margaret Chan (27 April 2009): Swine influenza |date=2009-04-27 |publisher=[[World Health Organization]]| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{flagicon|EU}} '''European Union''' (EU) Health Commissioner advises Europeans not to travel to the United States or Mexico unless the need is urgent. This follows the first confirmed case in Spain.<ref name="Guardian 27/4">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/apr/27/swine-flu-mexico|title=Europeans urged to avoid Mexico and US as swine flu death toll exceeds 100|date=27 April 2009|work=[[The Guardian]]|first=Daniel|last=Nasaw | location=London| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''' First six cases confirmed, four in Nova Scotia and two in British Columbia.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/health-officials-confirm-6-cases-of-swine-flu-in-canada-1.803361 | work=CBC News | title=Health officials confirm 6 cases of swine flu in Canada | date=2009-04-27| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{flagicon|Mexico}} '''Mexico''' First seven confirmed deaths<ref name="WHO">{{cite news|url=http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_04_27/en/index.html|title=Swine Influenza Update 3|date=27 April 2009|publisher=[[World Health Organization]]| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{flagicon|Spain}} '''Spain''' First confirmed case of swine flu, in [[Almansa]], and thus the first case in Europe; A(H1N1) has spread from the WHO Region of the Americas to the WHO European Region.<ref>[http://news.silobreaker.com/almansa-spain-11_167450 Almansa (Spain)]. Silobreaker</ref>
{{flagicon|UK}} ( {{flagicon|SCO}} ) '''United Kingdom''' First two confirmed cases, in Scotland.<ref>{{cite news|title=Scotland 'could help combat flu'|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/scotland/8023515.stm|accessdate=2018-01-28|work=[[BBC News]]|date=29 April 2009}}</ref>
====April 28====
{{flagicon|WHO}} '''WHO''' Confirmed cases are now extant in four of six WHO regions (see map). As of 19:15 GMT seven countries have officially reported cases of swine influenza A(H1N1) infection.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_04_28/en/index.html |title=WHO | Swine influenza - update 4 |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] |date=2009-04-28 |accessdate=2010-08-02 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100812191522/http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_04_28/en/index.html |archivedate=2010-08-12 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
{{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''' Confirmed: two cases and another four in [[Alberta]] and [[Ontario]], respectively.<ref name="canada.com">{{cite web |title=Swine flu: Mapping the H1N1 outbreak in Canada |author=Philip Ling |url=http://www.canada.com/Health/Swine+Mapping+H1N1+outbreak+Canada/1565858/story.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhPYQcTJ?url=http://www.canada.com/Health/Swine+Mapping+H1N1+outbreak+Canada/1565858/story.html |archivedate=2009-09-11 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|Israel}} '''Israel''' First confirmed case in Israel and thus the WHO Eastern Mediterranean Region (color-coded yellow), the third region to be affected.<ref>{{cite news |last=Xinhua |date=2009-04-28 |title=Israel confirms first case of swine flu |url=http://news.gaeatimes.com/israel-confirms-first-case-of-swine-flu-42122/ |work=The Gaea Times |accessdate=2013-12-20 }}</ref>
{{flagicon|New Zealand}} '''New Zealand''' First three confirmed cases in New Zealand and thus the WHO Western Pacific Region (color-coded red), the fourth region to be affected.<ref>{{cite press release| url=http://www.moh.govt.nz/moh.nsf/indexmh/results-of-h1n1-swine-flu-testing-280409 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090429231435/http://www.moh.govt.nz/moh.nsf/indexmh/results-of-h1n1-swine-flu-testing-280409 |title=RESULTS OF H1N1 (Swine flu) testing |publisher=New Zealand Ministry of Health |date=2009-04-28 |accessdate=2010-08-02 |archivedate=2009-04-29 }}</ref>
{{flagicon|Spain}} '''Spain''' The second confirmed case in Spain, in [[Valencia (province)|Valencia]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Spain confirms second case of swine flu |url=http://www.efluxmedia.com/news_Spain_confirms_second_case_of_swine_flu_37267.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhPSSqTY?url=http://www.efluxmedia.com/news_Spain_confirms_second_case_of_swine_flu_37267.html |archivedate=2009-09-11 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurosurveillance.org/images/dynamic/EE/V14N17/art19185.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090514175552/http://www.eurosurveillance.org/images/dynamic/EE/V14N17/art19185.pdf |format=PDF |title=Pandemic phase level 4: Human cases of the novel influenza A/H1N1 strain confirmed in Scotland and Spain |date=2009-04-30 |website=EUROSURVEILLANCE |publisher=European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control |accessdate=2013-12-20 |archivedate=2009-05-14 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
====April 29====
{{flagicon|WHO}} '''WHO''' The Emergency Committee meets for the third time,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hG6zmXnY6v5La-llZ8qbQIrdE-WAD97S4IP80 |title=WHO calls emergency meeting; eyes pandemic level |last=Jordans |first=Frank |author2=Cheng, Maria |date=2009-04-29 |publisher=Google News |agency=[[Associated Press]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5gQgjpMU0?url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hG6zmXnY6v5La-llZ8qbQIrdE-WAD97S4IP80 |archivedate=2009-04-30 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> and the '''WHO''' raises its pandemic alert level from Phase 4 to Phase 5, its second highest.<ref name="WHO-20090429-Chan">{{cite web |url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/statements/2009/h1n1_20090427/en/index.html |title=Statement by WHO Director-General, Dr Margaret Chan (29 April 2009): Swine influenza |date=2009-04-27 |publisher=[[World Health Organization]]| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> As of 1800 GMT, nine countries have officially reported 148 cases of swine influenza A(H1N1) infection.<ref name="who_a">{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_04_29/en/index.html |title=WHO | Influenza A(H1N1) - update 5 |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] |date=2009-04-29| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
'''ASEAN''' ASEAN officials are looking at coordinating measures to address the potential pandemic.<ref>{{cite web|title=Swine flu: Asean gears up |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?sec=nation&file=/2009/4/29/nation/20090429205847 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhQUloJ1?url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?sec=nation&file=%2F2009%2F4%2F29%2Fnation%2F20090429205847 |archivedate=2009-09-11 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|EU}} '''EU''' Foreign Relations Commissioner [[Benita Ferrero-Waldner]] announces that the halt of all travel to Mexico and disinfecting all airports due to the global flu outbreak is being considered.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://uk.reuters.com/article/2009/04/29/us-flu-eu-mexico-sb-idUKTRE53S3U120090429 | work=Reuters | title=EU considers halting all Mexico travel | date=2009-04-29| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{flagicon|Austria}} '''Austria''' First confirmed case.<ref name="who_a" />
{{flagicon|Germany}} '''Germany''' First three confirmed cases, two in [[Bavaria]] and one in [[Hamburg]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.agi.it/world/news/200904291257-cro-ren0021-swine_flu_germany_confirms_three_cases |title=SWINE FLU: GERMANY CONFIRMS THREE CASES |date=2009-04-29 |publisher=AGI |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5gSB1uiAh?url=http://www.agi.it/world/news/200904291257-cro-ren0021-swine_flu_germany_confirms_three_cases |archivedate=2009-05-01 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|Spain}} '''Spain''' Eight more cases raises the total in Spain to 10, including the first human-to-human intergenerational transmission<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/who-looking-for-signs-of-ongoing-swine-flu-spread-1.393576 |title=WHO looking for signs of ongoing swine flu spread |publisher=CTV.ca |date=2009-04-28 | accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> (in which the patient had not recently been to Mexico but was infected by another patient who had just visited Mexico, namely his girlfriend).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dailynews.muzi.com/news/ll/english/10089979.shtml?q=&cc=10314&a=on |title=Mexico begins five-day shutdown to fight swine flu - News - Muzi.com |publisher=Dailynews.muzi.com | accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> This is the first intergenerational transmission to be documented in Europe.
{{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' First death outside Mexico, a 23-month-old Mexican child hospitalized in Texas.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.cbsnews.com/news/us-h1n1-victim-visited-texas-mall/ | work=CBS News | title=U.S. H1N1 Victim Visited Texas Mall | date=2009-04-30| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> Ninety-one confirmed cases in the USA to date.<ref>{{cite web|title=Updated H1N1 (swine) influenza outbreak numbers from WHO : Worms and Germs Blog |author=Scott Weese |url=http://www.wormsandgermsblog.com/2009/04/articles/diseases/other-diseases/updated-h1n1-swine-influenza-outbreak-numbers-from-who/ |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhPco9T6?url=http://www.wormsandgermsblog.com/2009/04/articles/diseases/other-diseases/updated-h1n1-swine-influenza-outbreak-numbers-from-who/ |archivedate=2009-09-11 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|RSA}} '''South Africa''' First two cases reported within South Africa, by two women that travelled in Mexico weeks earlier. The cases were confirmed on 18 June 2009.
====April 30====
{{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''' Confirmed: One more case in [[Toronto]], and eight more cases in [[Nova Scotia]], and [[Alberta]] bringing total to 28.<ref name="spikeinCanadianCases">{{cite news | url = https://www.thestar.com/life/health_wellness/2009/04/30/ns_has_first_canadian_persontoperson_flu_case.html | location=Toronto | work=The Star | first=Tanya | last=Talaga | title=N.S. has first Canadian person-to-person flu case | date=2009-04-30| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{flagicon|Ireland}} '''Ireland''' First confirmed case.<ref name="Ireland 090501">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/8027601.stm|title=Irish man treated for swine flu|date=2009-04-30|publisher=BBC| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{flagicon|Netherlands}} '''Netherlands''' First confirmed case, a three-year-old child.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2009/04/30/idUSAAT007741 |title=Dutch confirm swine flu case in three year-old |publisher=Reuters |date=2009-04-30 | first=Reed | last=Stevenson| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> The child returned from Mexico to the Netherlands on April 27, 2009. The parents test negative for A(H1N1).
{{flagicon|Switzerland}} '''Switzerland''' First confirmed case.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2009/04/30/idUSLU680898|title=Switzerland confirms first case of swine flu|publisher=Reuters|date=2009-04-30| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' Four cases are confirmed in an outbreak at the [[University of Delaware]]; another 12 cases are deemed "probable". One of the confirmed cases is a baseball player, which results in the university cancelling sporting events, a concert by rapper [[Young Jeezy]], and other school activities.<ref name=miller2009>{{cite web |author=Miller, Beth |author2=Brown, Robin |author3=Riley, Emily |url=http://www.delawareonline.com/article/20090430/HEALTH/904300351 |title=More than 350 treated at UD |website=delawareonline |publisher=[[The News Journal]] |accessdate=2 August 2010 |date=3 May 2009 |archivedate=3 May 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503111617/http://www.delawareonline.com/article/20090430/HEALTH/904300351 }}</ref>
{{flagicon|UK}} '''United Kingdom''' Three further confirmed cases of swine flu, giving a total of eight confirmed cases.<ref>[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-05/01/content_11291535.htm "Three new cases of swine flu confirmed in Britain"] China View 1 May 2009</ref>
===May 2009===
====May 1====
{{flagicon|WHO}} '''WHO''' As of 0600 GMT, 11 countries have officially reported 331 cases of influenza A(H1N1) infection.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_05_01/en/index.html |title=WHO | Influenza A(H1N1) - update 7 |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] |accessdate=2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100717115331/http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_05_01/en/index.html |archivedate=17 July 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''' 51 confirmed cases.<ref>[http://www.ctvnews.ca/51-h1n1-flu-infections-confirmed-in-canada-1.394647 51 H1N1 flu infections confirmed in Canada - CTV News]. Ctv.ca (2009-05-01)</ref>
{{flagicon|Hong Kong}} '''[[Hong Kong, China]]''' *300 people are placed under quarantine at a hotel for seven days due to [[Hong Kong]]'s first confirmed case there.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/8029871.stm |title=Asia-Pacific | Hong Kong 'flu' hotel sealed off |publisher=BBC News |date=2007-04-18 | accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> *Chief Executive [[Donald Tsang]] raises Hong Kong's response level from "serious" to "emergency".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news.gov.hk/en/category/healthandcommunity/090501/html/090501en05004.htm |title=1st H1N1 case confirmed in HK |publisher=Hong Kong SAR |date=2009-05-01 |accessdate=2 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hLEg4fzu?url=http://www.news.gov.hk/en/category/healthandcommunity/090501/html/090501en05004.htm |archivedate=7 June 2009 |df= }}</ref> *The Director of Health, [[Dr. PY Lam]], orders Metropark Hotel in [[Wan Chai]] to be isolated for seven days.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chp.gov.hk/en/view_content/16783.html |title= Director of Health issues isolation order to control human swine flu |publisher=[[Centre for Health Protection]]|date=2009-05-31| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{flagicon|Denmark}} '''Denmark''' First confirmed case (in Hvidovre).<ref>{{cite news |first=Marie Joo Kim |last=Jensen |url=http://www.bt.dk/nyheder/dansk-kvinde-smittet-med-h1n1-influenza-efter-new-york-rejse |title=Dansk kvinde smittet med H1N1-influenza efter New York-rejse |language=Danish |trans-title=Danish woman infected with the H1N1 flu after the New York trip |work=BT |date=2008-12-16 |accessdate=2013-12-20 }}</ref>
{{flagicon|France}} '''France''' First two confirmed cases.<ref>{{cite web |date=2009-05-01<!-- 19:00--> |format=PDF |url=http://www.invs.sante.fr/derniere_minute/fichiers/10.bilan01052009_19h00.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090520224452/http://www.invs.sante.fr/derniere_minute/fichiers/10.bilan01052009_19h00.pdf |title=Sujets suspects et cas de nouvelle grippe A(H1N1) en France |language=French |trans-title=Suspicious subjects and cases of new influenza A (H1N1) in France |accessdate=2010-08-02 |archivedate=2009-05-20 }}</ref>
{{flagicon|Mexico}} '''Mexico''' begins an unprecedented five-day shutdown to fight the spread of the flu.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allheadlinenews.com/articles/7014992858 |title= Mexico To Close Down Most Businesses For Five Days As 331 Cases Of Swine Flu Reported |publisher=AHN |date=2009-05-01| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{flagicon|UK}} '''United Kingdom''' First and second case of human to human (or intergenerational) transmission within the UK confirmed.<ref>{{cite web|title=First case of onward human to human swine flu transmission in England confirmed |author=HPA |url=http://www.hpa.org.uk/webw/HPAweb&HPAwebStandard/HPAweb_C/1241180239108?p=1231252394302 |accessdate=2 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090504060722/http://www.hpa.org.uk/webw/HPAweb%26HPAwebStandard/HPAweb_C/1241180239108?p=1231252394302 |archivedate=4 May 2009 |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' 155 confirmed cases, including two at George Washington University's Thurston Hall.<ref>{{cite web|title=H1N1 virus hits campus | UWIRE |url=http://www.uwire.com/Article.aspx?id=4076458 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhQRVh9F?url=http://www.uwire.com/Article.aspx?id=4076458 |archivedate=2009-09-11 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
====May 2====
{{flagicon|WHO}} '''[[WHO]]''' As of 0600 GMT 15 countries have officially reported 615 cases of influenza A(H1N1) infection.<ref name="index1">{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_05_02/en/index.html |title=WHO | Influenza A(H1N1) - update 9 |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] |accessdate=2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100717115233/http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_05_02/en/index.html |archivedate=17 July 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|Canada}} '''[[Canada]]''' [[Canadian Food Inspection Agency|The Canadian Food Inspection Agency]] confirms the first human-to-animal transmission of the virus after an [[Albertan]] returns from Mexico and infects a pig farm, the first known case of (reverse) [[zoonosis]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Worker may have passed H1N1 to Alberta pigs |publisher=CTV |date=2009-05-02 |url=http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20090502/swineflu_pigs_090502/20090502/?hub=TorontoNewHome |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503195703/http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20090502/swineflu_pigs_090502/20090502/?hub=TorontoNewHome |accessdate=2010-08-02 |archivedate=2009-05-03 }}</ref>
{{flagicon|China}} '''[[China]]''' suspends flights from Mexico to [[Shanghai]] when a case is confirmed on a flight from Mexico.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.globaltimes.cn/china/Policies/2009-05/428924.html |title=China halts Mexico flights as flu hits | newspaper=Shanghai Daily |publisher=Global Times |date=2009-05-03 |accessdate=2013-12-20 }}</ref>
{{flagicon|ROK}} '''[[South Korea]]''' First confirmed case.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_05_02/en/index.html |title=1st South Korea case |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] |accessdate=2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100717115233/http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_05_02/en/index.html |archivedate=17 July 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|United States}} '''[[United States]]''' There are more than 430 school closures in 18 states.<ref name=wener2009>{{cite news |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090502/ap_on_re_us/us_med_swine_flu_us |title=More schools shut as swine flu spreads in US |last1=Werner |first1=Erica |date=2 May 2009 |archivedate=5 May 2009 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |website=[[Yahoo! News]] |accessdate=10 June 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090505130558/https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090502/ap_on_re_us/us_med_swine_flu_us }}</ref> CDC FluView Week 17: Widespread activity in seven states, regional activity in 12.<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/weeklyarchives2008-2009/weekly17.htm CDC - Influenza (Flu)|Weekly Report: Influenza Summary Update Week 17, 2008-2009 Season]. Cdc.gov</ref>
====May 3==== {{flagicon|WHO}} '''WHO''' As of 0600 GMT, 17 countries have officially reported 787 cases of (A)H1N1.<ref name="index1" />
{{flagicon|Arab League}} '''Arab League''' Health Ministers meet in Riyadh, to discuss human and technical support to be deployed in any Arab affected place.<ref>{{cite news|title=Arab health ministers meet on swine flu|url=https://www.kuna.net.kw/ArticleDetails.aspx?id=1995206&language=en|accessdate=2018-01-28|work=KUNA|date=2009-05-03}}</ref>
{{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''' 101 confirmed cases after seven cases in [[British Columbia]], three in [[Alberta]], two in [[Nova Scotia]] and [[Ontario]], and one in [[Quebec]] were confirmed.<ref name="CBC 3May09">{{cite news|title=Swine flu epidemic on decline: Mexico |publisher=CBC |date=2009-05-03 |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/swine-flu-epidemic-in-decline-mexico-1.778034 |accessdate=2018-01-28}}</ref>
{{flagicon|Colombia}} '''Colombia''' First confirmed case in [[South America]].<ref name="CBC 3May09"/>
====May 4==== {{flagicon|WHO}} '''WHO''' As of 06:00 GMT, 20 countries have officially reported 985 cases of influenza A (H1N1) infection.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_05_04/en/index.html |title=WHO | Influenza A(H1N1) — update 13 |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] |accessdate=2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100717115042/http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_05_04/en/index.html |archivedate=17 July 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref name=WHOcasemap2009>{{cite web |url=http://whoterrance.vo.msecnd.net/mediacentre/swine_flu/GlobalSubnationalMaster_20090504_0630.jpg |title=New Influenza A (H1N1): Number of laboratory confirmed cases and deaths |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=4 May 2009 |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] |accessdate=13 June 2013 |archivedate=7 May 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090507101228/http://whoterrance.vo.msecnd.net/mediacentre/swine_flu/GlobalSubnationalMaster_20090504_0630.jpg |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''' A girl from [[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]] was diagnosed with a severe case of the H1N1 virus.<ref name="Canada identifies first severe flu case">{{cite web|url=http://news.brisbanetimes.com.au/breaking-news-world/canada-identifies-first-severe-flu-case-20090505-asxl.html|title=Canada identifies first severe flu case|date=May 5, 2009|location = Australia|publisher=[[Brisbane Times]]| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
====May 5==== {{flagicon|WHO}} '''WHO''' As of 06:00 GMT, 21 countries have officially reported 1,124 cases of influenza A (H1N1) infection.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_05_05/en/index.html |title=WHO | Influenza A(H1N1) - update 15 |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] |accessdate=2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100717114851/http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_05_05/en/index.html |archivedate=17 July 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|United States}} '''United States'''
*Second confirmed death, the first of a U.S. resident, a pregnant special education teacher in Texas: Judy Trunnell. The 33-year-old gives birth to her second child via [[Caesarian section]] during her eighth month of pregnancy, in a [[coma]] whilst on [[life support]].<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Second U.S. death linked to swine flu, officials say |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/HEALTH/05/05/swine.flu.main/index.html |work=CNN Health |publisher=CNN |date=2009-05-05 |accessdate=2013-12-20 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.keyetv.com/content/news/topnews/story/Texas-H1N1-victim-had-chronic-respiratory/GpbohHBWAkaATQrWhnzGMg.cspx |accessdate=May 8, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120226142941/http://www.keyetv.com/content/news/topnews/story/Texas-H1N1-victim-had-chronic-respiratory/GpbohHBWAkaATQrWhnzGMg.cspx |archivedate=February 26, 2012|title=Texas H1N1 victim had chronic respiratory...}}<!-- not present in archive.org --></ref> Judy Trunnell had several underlying medical conditions, most notably [[asthma]].<ref>[http://www.nbcnews.com/id/30398682/ Pregnant women more at risk from swine flu - Health - Cold and flu - Swine flu - msnbc.com]. MSNBC (2009-05-14)</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/09/health/09flu.html?_r=1|work=The New York Times|title=Other Illness May Precede Worst Cases of Swine Flu|date=2009-05-09|first=Donald G.|last=Mcneil Jr.| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/h1n1flu/parents.htm CDC H1N1 Flu|Information for Concerned Parents and Caregivers]. Cdc.gov</ref> *Several sailors in San Diego, California fall ill (including a sailor on the [[USS Dubuque (LPD-8)|USS Dubuque]], which results in the cancellation of its deployment). These are the first cases in the U.S. Navy.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/8034991.stm |title=Americas | US navy halts aid vessel over flu |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-04-28 | accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> *As the low level of virulence of novel A(H1N1) in the U.S. becomes established, the CDC issues revised criteria for school closures, effectively ending widespread shutdowns.<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/h1n1flu/k12_dismissal.htm CDC H1N1 Flu |] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090506020854/http://www.cdc.gov/h1n1flu/K12_dismissal.htm |date=2009-05-06 }}. Cdc.gov (2009-08-07)</ref>
====May 6==== {{flagicon|WHO}} '''WHO''' As of 06:00 GMT, 22 countries have officially reported 1,516 cases of influenza A (H1N1) infection.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_05_06/en/index.html |title=WHO | Influenza A(H1N1) - update 17 |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] |accessdate=2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100717114753/http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_05_06/en/index.html |archivedate=17 July 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
'''ASEAN''' A special regional summit to fight possible swine flu pandemic was held in Bangkok and was attended by senior ASEAN health officials along with those from China, Japan and South Korea.<ref>{{cite web|title=ASEAN swine flu summit in Bangkok |url=http://www.mizzima.com/news/regional/2084-asean-swine-flu-summit-in-bangkok.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhQWcUiF?url=http://www.mizzima.com/news/regional/2084-asean-swine-flu-summit-in-bangkok.html |archivedate=2009-09-11 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|Guatemala}} '''Guatemala''' First confirmed case, and the first in Central America.<ref>{{cite web|title=H5N1: Guatemala: First case of H1N1 |url=http://crofsblogs.typepad.com/h5n1/2009/05/guatemala-first-case-of-h1n1.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhQEI2c3?url=http://crofsblogs.typepad.com/h5n1/2009/05/guatemala-first-case-of-h1n1.html |archivedate=2009-09-11 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref>[http://www.lahora.com.gt/notas.php?key=48270&fch=2009-05-05 Spanish-language reportage] {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
{{flagicon|Poland}} '''Poland''' First confirmed case.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2009/05/06/idUSL631134 | work=Reuters | title=First H1N1 flu case reported in Poland-PAP news agency | date=2009-05-06| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{flagicon|Sweden}} '''Sweden''' First confirmed case.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://uk.reuters.com/article/2009/05/06/uk-flu-sweden-sb-idUKTRE54536B20090506 | work=Reuters | title=Sweden confirms first case of H1N1 flu | date=2009-05-06| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
====May 7==== {{flagicon|WHO}} '''WHO''' As of 18:00 GMT, 24 countries have officially reported 2,371 cases of influenza A (H1N1) infection.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_05_07a/en/index.html |title=WHO | Influenza A(H1N1) - update 20 |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] |accessdate=2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100717114612/http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_05_07a/en/index.html |archivedate=17 July 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|Argentina}} '''Argentina''' First confirmed case.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=1125546&pid=6391198&toi=6256 |title=Confirmaron el primer caso de gripe porcina en la Argentina |publisher=lanacion.com | accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{flagicon|Brazil}} '''Brazil''' First four confirmed cases.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stabroek News - Brazil confirms 4 cases of H1N1 flu-minister |url=http://www.stabroeknews.com/2009/news/world/05/08/brazil-confirms-4-cases-of-h1n1-flu-minister/ |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhQRtXhO?url=http://www.stabroeknews.com/2009/news/world/05/08/brazil-confirms-4-cases-of-h1n1-flu-minister/ |archivedate=2009-09-11 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref>[http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/afp_world/view/428001/1/.html Channel NewsAsia - Brazil confirms first domestically transmitted H1N1 flu case]. channelnewsasia.com (2009-05-09)</ref>
{{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''' Reports suggest that an elderly woman who had swine flu has died in northern Alberta, marking the first death in Canada related to swine flu.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/health/story/2009/05/07/edmonton-swine-flu-death.html |title=Reports suggest elderly Alberta woman with swine flu has died |publisher=cbc.ca |date=May 7, 2009 |accessdate=2 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090511043853/http://www.cbc.ca/health/story/2009/05/07/edmonton-swine-flu-death.html |archivedate=11 May 2009 |df= }}</ref> Furthermore, an unusual case of zoonosis occurred when a swine flu inspector in improper gear caught the virus from an infected pig.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/calgary/story/2009/07/20/swine-flu-inspectors-improper-gear-virus-calgary.html |publisher=CBC News |date=20 July 2009 |title=Swine-flu inspectors in improper gear got virus |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jgq6kctt?url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/calgary/story/2009/07/20/swine-flu-inspectors-improper-gear-virus-calgary.html |archivedate=10 September 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|The Netherlands}} '''The Netherlands''' Second case confirmed, a 53-year-old woman who had recently travelled to Mexico.<ref>[http://vorige.nrc.nl/international/article2235486.ece/Second_case_of_H1N1_flu_in_the_Netherlands International - Second case of H1N1 flu in the Netherlands]. nrc.nl (2009-05-07)</ref>
{{flagicon|USA}} '''USA''' The [[New England Journal of Medicine]] establishes its H1N1 Influenza Center on its website.<ref>[http://h1n1.nejm.org/ H1N1 Influenza Center|From the Publishers of the New England Journal of Medicine] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170602210128/http://h1n1.nejm.org/ |date=2017-06-02 }}. H1n1.nejm.org</ref>
====May 8==== {{flagicon|WHO}} '''WHO''' As of 16:00 GMT, 25 countries have officially reported 2,500 cases of influenza A (H1N1) infection.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_05_08a/en/index.html |title=WHO | Influenza A(H1N1) - update 22 |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] |accessdate=2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100717114223/http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_05_08a/en/index.html |archivedate=17 July 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|Japan}} '''Japan''' First three confirmed cases.<ref>{{cite web|date=May 8, 2009T|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jRvNCET42y1RZUWhqEoAtZUDcuBg|title=Three Japanese test positive for swine flu|publisher=AFP| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{flagicon|Panama}} '''Panama''' First confirmed case.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-world/panamas-first-swine-flu-case-confirmed-20090509-ay8h.html | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | title=Panama's first swine flu case confirmed | date=2009-05-09| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref>[http://www.thaindian.com/newsportal/health1/panama-reports-first-swine-flu-case_100190134.html Panama reports first swine flu case]. Thaindian.com (2009-05-09)</ref><ref>[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-05/09/content_11339331.htm Panama confirms first case of A/H1N1 flu_English_Xinhua]. News.xinhuanet.com (2009-05-09)</ref>
====May 9==== {{flagicon|WHO}} '''WHO''' As of 06:00 GMT, 29 countries have officially reported 3,440 cases of influenza A(H1N1) infection.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_05_09/en/index.html |title=WHO ; Influenza A(H1N1) - update 23 |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] |accessdate=2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100717114147/http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_05_09/en/index.html |archivedate=17 July 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|AUS}} '''Australia''' First confirmed case.<ref name=QLD>{{cite news |title=First confirmed case of swine flu in Australia |publisher=[[News Limited]] |date=9 May 2009 |archivedate=11 May 2009 |url=http://www.news.com.au/story/0,27574,25452286-5018988,00.html |accessdate=2 August 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090511005950/http://www.news.com.au/story/0%2C27574%2C25452286-5018988%2C00.html |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|BRA}} '''Brazil''' Two cases confirmed, one of which is thought to be the first case of human-to-human infection in Brazil.<ref>{{cite news|title = Brasil permanece com 30 casos suspeitos da nova gripe|publisher = g1.globo.com|date = 2009-05-09|url = http://g1.globo.com/Sites/Especiais/Noticias/0,,MUL1115117-16726,00-BRASIL+PERMANECE+COM+CASOS+SUSPEITOS+DA+NOVA+GRIPE.html| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{flagicon|CRI}} '''Costa Rica''' First confirmed death, and also the first death outside of North America.<ref name="ticos1">{{cite web|url=http://www.nacion.com/ln_ee/2009/mayo/09/pais1959686.html |title=Muere primer tico contagiado de gripe AH1N1 |publisher=[[La Nación (Costa Rica)|La Nación]] |date=2009-05-09 |language=Spanish |accessdate=2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot--> |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090513094224/http://www.nacion.com/ln_ee/2009/mayo/09/pais1959686.html |archivedate=May 13, 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref name="ticos2">{{cite web |url=http://www.abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory?id=7545376|title=Costa Rica Sees 1st Swine Flu Death |publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=2009-05-09 | accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> Three other confirmed cases, all children, were contaminated by the patient who died.<ref name="ticos3">{{cite web|url=http://www.nacion.com/ln_ee/2009/mayo/09/pais1959751.html |title=Tres niños con gripe AH1N1 fueron contagiados por tico que falleció esta madrugada |publisher=[[La Nación (Costa Rica)|La Nación]] |date=2009-05-09 |language=Spanish |accessdate=2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot--> |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090513095422/http://www.nacion.com/ln_ee/2009/mayo/09/pais1959751.html |archivedate=13 May 2009 |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|Japan}} '''Japan''' 4th confirmed case, a schoolmate of the first three cases.<ref name=nhk2009>{{cite news |title=Japan Confirms 4th Case Of Swine Flu |author= |url=http://www.pacificnewscenter.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=7824:japan-records1st-swine-flu-case&catid=34:guam&Itemid=141 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090715100127/http://www.pacificnewscenter.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=7824%3Ajapan-records1st-swine-flu-case&catid=34%3Aguam&Itemid=141 |agency=[[NHK]] |date=10 May 2009 |archivedate=15 July 2009 |accessdate=9 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>

{{flagicon|WHO}} '''WHO''' Most countries in the Southern Hemisphere (represented by Chile, Argentina, New Zealand, and Australia) appear to have passed their peak of influenza activity and returned to baseline activity.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
{{flagicon|EU}} '''[[ECDC]]''' Based partially on data from the Southern Hemisphere, the ECDC forecasts a first wave of infections in autumn and winter which stresses hospitals in particular; it is noted, however, that "the overall interruption of essential services in (well-prepared) countries has been manageable".<ref>[http://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/press/news/Lists/News/ECDC_DispForm.aspx?List=32e43ee8-e230-4424-a783-85742124029a&ID=297&RootFolder=%2Fen%2Fpress%2Fnews%2FLists%2FNews News - New ECDC pandemic risk assessment]. {{flagicon|Brazil}} '''Brazil''' 602 H1N1 deaths confirmed, the highest number of any nation-state to date.<ref>{{cite web|title=A/H1N1 Swine Flu (Influenza) Timeline | August 29: Brazil (BR): 602 deaths confirmed |url=http://trancy.net/2009/08/29/august-29-brazil-br-602-deaths-confirmed/ |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ji4c9fjR?url=http://trancy.net/2009/08/29/august-29-brazil-br-602-deaths-confirmed/ |archivedate=2009-09-11 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' CDC FluView Week 34: Influenza activity, which had been largely stable or decreasing in prior weeks, increases in the U.S. "Six states and Puerto Rico reported geographically widespread influenza activity, 13 states reported regional influenza activity, 10 states and the District of Columbia reported local influenza activity, 19 states reported sporadic influenza activity, two states reported no influenza activity, and Guam and the U.S. Virgin Islands did not report." Furthermore, Region IV, i.e. the Southeast, reports increased out-patient ILI above its regional baseline.<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/weeklyarchives2008-2009/weekly34.htm CDC - Influenza (Flu)|Weekly Report: Influenza Summary Update Week 34, 2008-2009 Season]. Cdc.gov</ref>

{{flagicon|Norway}} '''Norway''' First death confirmed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metronews.ca/toronto/live/article/300693--norway-announced-1st-confirmed-victim-of-swine-flu-a-danish-truck-driver |title=Norway announced 1st confirmed victim of swine flu, a Danish truck driver |date=2009-09-03 |publisher=metronews.ca |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jiAbtQfy?url=http://www.metronews.ca/toronto/live/article/300693--norway-announced-1st-confirmed-victim-of-swine-flu-a-danish-truck-driver |archivedate=2009-09-11 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|USA}} '''United States''' The [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] in its [[Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report (MMWR) |url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/ |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jiAe2aKp?url=http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/ |archivedate=2009-09-11 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> notes that 67% of thirty-six children who have died from H1N1 early in the epidemic had at least one serious chronic medical condition, with neurodevelopmental conditions such as developmental delay, epilepsy, and cerebral palsy being especially prominent.<ref>{{cite web|title=CDC: Any healthy child can get H1N1 flu - UPI.com |url=http://www.upi.com/Health_News/2009/09/03/CDC-Any-healthy-child-can-get-H1N1-flu/UPI-10311251998916/ |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jiAeRcio?url=http://www.upi.com/Health_News/2009/09/03/CDC-Any-healthy-child-can-get-H1N1-flu/UPI-10311251998916/ |archivedate=2009-09-11 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Roughly one in thirteen deaths have been of school-age children. More than 80% of the children who died were five or older, in contrast with the seasonal flu baseline of half or more of the influenza fatalities being four or younger.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/09/03/health/main5285670.shtml | work=CBS News | title=CDC: Older Kids May Have Greater H1N1 Risk | date=2009-09-03| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
====September 4====
{{flagicon|Italy}} '''Italy''' First death confirmed.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.adnkronos.com/AKI/English/Security/?id=3.0.3731048586| title=Swine Flu: First death confirmed in Italy| date= 2009-09-04| publisher=adnkronos.com| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
====September 5==== {{flagicon|USA}} '''United States''' CDC FluView Week 35: Influenza increases in the U.S. with widespread influenza activity in 11 states and regional activity in 13; the proportion of outpatient visits for influenza-like illness (ILI) is above the national baseline, with four out of ten HHS Surveillance Regions reporting ILI above region-specific baselines. "97% of all subtyped influenza A viruses being reported to CDC were 2009 influenza A (H1N1) viruses."<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/weeklyarchives2008-2009/weekly35.htm CDC - Seasonal Influenza (Flu) - Weekly Report: Influenza Summary Update]. Cdc.gov</ref>
