{{flagicon|Mozambique}} '''Mozambique''' First death confirmed, that of a 29-year-old female with an unspecified chronic illness.<ref>[http://www.straitstimes.com/Breaking%2BNews/World/Story/STIStory_430154.html 1st H1N1 death in Mozambique]. Straitstimes.com (2009-09-15)</ref>
====September 17====
{{flagicon|Malta}} '''Malta''' Third death confirmed.<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk"/>
{{flagicon|Netherlands}} '''Netherlands''' The third and fourth deaths are confirmed, that of a 52-year-old man and an 85-year-old woman, respectively, both of whom had underlying medical conditions.<ref name=n1>{{cite web|title=Nieuwe Influenza A (H1N1) |url=http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/H1N1overzicht_tcm92-61018.pdf |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5k5m7vYew?url=http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/H1N1overzicht_tcm92-61018.pdf |archivedate=2009-09-27 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|United Kingdom}} '''United Kingdom''' Health Minister Andy Burnham states that the second peak of swine flu has started as 5,000 people contracted the virus this week, compared to 3,000 the week before.<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk">{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/8261496.stm|work=BBC News|title=Fears swine flu 'on the way back'|date=2009-09-17 | first=Nick | last=Triggle| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
====September 18====
{{flagicon|Martinique}} '''Martinique''' First death confirmed, that of an 18-month-old girl.<ref>[http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20090918/h1n1_martinique_090918/20090918?hub=Health Martinique reports first death from swine flu - CTV News]. Ctv.ca (2009-09-18)</ref>
====September 19====
{{flagicon|Malaysia}} '''Malaysia''' One more death confirmed. Total: 77 deaths.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/articles/20090919132223/Article/index_html |title=Influenza A(H1N1): Death toll now 77 |date=2009-09-19 |publisher=NST Online |accessdate=2 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090923143730/http://nst.com.my/Current_News/NST/articles/20090919132223/Article/index_html |archivedate=23 September 2009 |df= }}
{{flagicon|US}}</ref> '''United States''' CDC FluView Week 37: Widespread influenza activity in twenty-six states, regional activity in 11. All of the HHS ILI regions report elevated levels of influenza activity above their region-specific baselines except for Region I (New England).<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/weeklyarchives2008-2009/weekly37.htm CDC - Seasonal Influenza (Flu) - Weekly Report: Influenza Summary Update]. Cdc.gov</ref>
====September 20==== {{flagicon|WHO}} '''WHO''' Over 3,917 deaths worldwide are reported.<ref>[http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_09_25/en/index.html WHO|Pandemic (H1N1) 2009 - update 67]. Who.int</ref>
====September 21====
{{flagicon|China}} '''China''' A national vaccination campaign begins in China, making it the first country to issue the H1N1 vaccine.<ref>Barriaux, Marianne. (2009-09-21) [https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jnZjqbJ39in-UlGp4Z3wwcc2xKuQ AFP: China begins mass vaccinations for swine flu]. Google.com</ref>
{{flagicon|U.S.}} '''United States''' The U.S. government orders a total of 251 million doses of H1N1 vaccine from manufacturers, up from the long-planned total of 195 million.<ref>[http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/164895.php Government Orders Additional H1N1 Vaccine]. Medicalnewstoday.com</ref>
====September 23====
{{flagicon|Portugal}} '''Portugal''' The first death confirmed, that of a Portuguese man living in France.<ref>{{cite web |title=A/H1N1 Swine Flu (Influenza) Timeline | September 24: Portugal (PT): First death confirmed |url=http://trancy.net/2009/09/24/september-24-portugal-pt-first-death-confirmed |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5k5uRvkNl?url=http://trancy.net/2009/09/24/september-24-portugal-pt-first-death-confirmed |archivedate=2009-09-27 |deadurl=yes |df= |access-date=2009-09-24 }}</ref>
====September 25====
{{flagicon|Germany}} '''Germany''' First death confirmed, that of a 36-year-old woman who died of a so-called [[superinfection]] which included H1N1.<ref>{{cite web|title=Schweinegrippe: Erster H1N1-Todesfall ins Gelsenkirchen Deutschland - News - Bild.de |url=http://www.bild.de/BILD/news/2009/09/26/schweinegrippe/erster-h1n1-todesfall-in-gelsenkirchen-deutschland.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5k8bO0Jt0?url=http://www.bild.de/BILD/news/2009/09/26/schweinegrippe/erster-h1n1-todesfall-in-gelsenkirchen-deutschland.html |archivedate=2009-09-29 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
{{flagicon|USA}} '''United States''' Forty-two schools are closed in eight states as the second wave of the pandemic begins in early autumn.<ref name="washingtonpost1">{{cite news|title=Swine Flu Surge Closes Schools, Tests Hospitals - washingtonpost.com |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/09/26/AR2009092601254.html?hpid=topnews |work=The Washington Post |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5kAv3Gqrr?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/09/26/AR2009092601254.html?hpid=topnews |archivedate=2009-09-30 |first=Rob |last=Stein |date=2009-09-27 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
====September 26====
{{flagicon|USA}} '''United States''' CDC FluView Week 38: Widespread influenza activity in twenty-seven states, regional activity in 18.<ref name="autogenerated3">[https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/weeklyarchives2008-2009/weekly38.htm CDC - Seasonal Influenza (Flu) - Weekly Report: Influenza Summary Update]. Cdc.gov</ref>
====September 27====
{{flagicon|WHO}} '''WHO''' At least 4,108 deaths worldwide are reported.<ref>[http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_10_02/en/index.html WHO|Pandemic (H1N1) 2009 - update 68]. Who.int</ref>
{{flagicon|USA}} '''United States''' The second wave of the H1N1 pandemic begins to stress hospitals in the U.S. and prompts some school closures.<ref name="washingtonpost1"/><ref>{{cite web|title=VOA News - H1N1 Swine Flu Keeps Hospitals in Northern Hemisphere Busy |url=http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-09-24-voa36.cfm |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5kDEm2bFV?url=http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-09-24-voa36.cfm |archivedate=2009-10-02 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
====September 28==== {{flagicon|Cambodia}} '''Cambodia''' First death confirmed, in Phnom Penh.<ref name="health.yahoo.com">{{cite web|url=http://health.yahoo.com/news/afp/healthflucambodia_20090928161927.html |accessdate=September 29, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5kNKQfUGC?url=http://health.yahoo.com/news/afp/healthflucambodia_20090928161927.html |archivedate=October 8, 2009 |title=Cambodia records first swine flu death: PM |df= }} [http://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/officials-confirm-flu-death Officials confirm flu death]</ref>
====September 29==== {{flagicon|Ireland}} '''Ireland''' First case of reverse zoonosis in pigs.<ref name="edp24.co.uk">[http://www.edp24.co.uk/content/edp24/news/story.aspx?brand=EDPOnline&category=News&tBrand=EDPOnline&tCategory=xDefault&itemid=NOED02+Dec+2009+17%3A57%3A07%3A610 Norfolk pigs catch swine flu - Norfolk News]. EDP24</ref>

{{flagicon|Australia}} '''Australia''' Mass vaccination drive begins, the second in the world.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE58T1NM20090930 | work=Reuters | title=Australia rolls out nationwide swine flu vaccination | date=2009-09-30 | first=Fayen | last=Wong| accessdate= 22 October 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{flagicon|Bulgaria}} '''Bulgaria''' First death confirmed.<ref name="health.yahoo.com"/>
{{flagicon|China}} '''China''' Sinovac Biotech Ltd., the first company worldwide to complete clinical trials for a vaccine, receives an order for an additional 3 million doses of H1N1 vaccine from the PRC government, making for a total of 6.3 million doses.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/rbssHealthcareNews/idUSBNG35020720090930 | work=Reuters | title=UPDATE 1-China's Sinovac gets additional order for H1N1 vaccine | date=2009-09-30| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref>[http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/161291.php H1N1 Vaccine Orders Top 1B, WHO Says]. Medicalnewstoday.com</ref>
{{flagicon|U.S.}} '''United States''' 46 states and Washington, D.C. begin ordering what becomes by the next day a cumulative total of 1,378,200 doses of the nasal-spray Live Attenuated Influenza Vaccine ([[LAIV]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flu.gov/individualfamily/vaccination/orders.html |accessdate=October 5, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091003170544/http://www.flu.gov/individualfamily/vaccination/orders.html |archivedate=October 3, 2009 |title=Orders for Live Attenuated Influenza Vaccine}}</ref> for H1N1.
===October 2009===
====October 3==== {{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' CDC FluView Week 39: The proportion of deaths attributed to pneumonia and influenza (P&I) reaches the epidemic threshold with eight out of ten HHS ILI regions reporting region-specific ILI activity above region-specific baseline levels. Widespread influenza activity in thirty-seven states, regional activity in 11.<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/weeklyarchives2008-2009/weekly39.htm CDC - Seasonal Influenza (Flu) - Weekly Report: Influenza Summary Update]. Cdc.gov</ref>
====October 4====
{{flagicon|WHO}} '''WHO''' At least 4,525 deaths worldwide are reported.<ref name="ReferenceB">[http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_10_09/en/index.html WHO|Pandemic (H1N1) 2009 - update 69]. Who.int</ref>
{{flagicon|Tajikistan}} '''Tajikistan''' First case confirmed.<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
{{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' The CDC's 2009–10 influenza season officially begins.<ref name="autogenerated3"/><ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/flu/about/season/current-season.htm CDC - Seasonal Influenza (Flu) - 2009-10 Influenza (Flu) Season]. Cdc.gov</ref>
====October 5==== {{flagicon|UN}} '''United Nations''' Rich countries should make more vaccines available to poorer nations where the H1N1 virus is starting to hit, United Nations health officials said. They said increased readiness for swine flu was needed in developing countries with weaker medical systems and with large, young populations, who are most vulnerable to the disease. Some countries, such as the United States, Brazil and France, have agreed to make 10 percent of their national vaccine stockpile available to developing countries. Manufacturers have also donated about 150 million doses of vaccine.<ref>[http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=31&art_id=nw20091004233828440C114736 News - Science: UN calls for sharing of flu vaccines]. Iol.co.za</ref>
====October 6==== {{flagicon|China}} '''China''' First death confirmed, in [[Lhasa]], [[Tibet]].<ref>[http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20091006/flu_china_091006/20091006?hub=Health China reports 1st swine flu death - CTV News]. Ctv.ca</ref>
{{flagicon|Tanzania}} '''Tanzania''' First death confirmed.
====October 9==== {{flagicon|Yemen}} '''Yemen''' Tamiflu resistance found.<ref name="emro.who.int"/>
====October 10==== {{flagicon|Cuba}} '''Cuba''' First deaths confirmed, that of three pregnant women.<ref>[http://asia.news.yahoo.com/afp/20091010/twl-health-flu-cuba-4bdc673_1.html Yahoo! News]. Asia.news.yahoo.com {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
{{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' CDC FluView Week 40: The proportion of deaths attributed to pneumonia and influenza (P&I) is officially above the epidemic threshold. Moreover, for the first time all 10 HHS ILI regions reported ILI above region-specific baseline levels. Widespread influenza activity in forty-one states, and regional activity in eight, with only one state—Hawaii—reporting local influenza activity.<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/weeklyarchives2009-2010/weekly40.htm CDC - Seasonal Influenza (Flu) - Weekly Report: Influenza Summary Update]. Cdc.gov</ref>
====October 11==== {{flagicon|WHO}} '''WHO''' At least 4,735 deaths worldwide are reported.<ref>[http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_10_16/en/index.html WHO|Pandemic (H1N1) 2009 - update 70]. Who.int</ref>

{{flagicon|Norway}} '''Norway''' first case of reverse zoonosis detected in [[Nord-Trøndelag]].<ref>[http://theforeigner.no/pages/news/swine-flu-found-in-norwegian-pigs/ Swine flu found in Norwegian pigs / News / The Foreigner — Norwegian News in English]. Theforeigner.no</ref>
{{flagicon|Rwanda}} '''Rwanda''' First cases confirmed.<ref name=afro>[http://www.afro.who.int/ddc/influenzaa/index.html Disease Prevention & Control Cluster (DPC) - WHO|Regional Office for Africa]. Afro.who.int</ref>
{{flagicon|São Tomé and Príncipe}} '''São Tomé and Príncipe''' First cases confirmed.<ref name=afro/>

{{flagicon|Vietnam}} '''Vietnam''' Three cases of Tamiflu resistance (which developed during hospital treatment) are confirmed. The resistant strains were apparently not transmitted, and all three patients survived.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/GCA-SwineFlu/idUSTRE59B0WH20091012 | work=Reuters | title=Vietnam detects 3 cases of drug-resistant swine flu | date=2009-10-12| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
====October 13==== {{flagicon|Mongolia}} '''Mongolia''' First cases confirmed.<ref>[http://mongolianviews.blogspot.com/2009/10/breaking-news-swine-flu-outbreak-in.html Mongolian Views: Breaking news: Swine flu outbreak in Mongolia]. Mongolianviews.blogspot.com (2009-10-13)</ref>
====October 15==== {{flagicon|India}} '''India''' Six more deaths confirmed. Total: 405 deaths.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://pib.nic.in/release/release.asp?relid=53224| title=Consolidated Status of Influenza A H1N1 - 15th October 2009| date= 2009-10-15| publisher=PIB Press Release| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{flagicon|Trinidad and Tobago}} '''Trinidad and Tobago''' First death confirmed.<ref>[http://guardian.co.tt/news/general/2009/10/15/tt-has-first-swine-flu-deaths T&T has first swine flu deaths|The Trinidad Guardian]. Guardian.co.tt (2009-10-15)</ref>
{{flagicon|United Kingdom}} '''United Kingdom''' The death toll passes 100. Total confirmed deaths: 106. The NHS confirms that second wave of swine flu has begun, with cases in Wales and Northern Ireland being especially high. The Minister of Health confirms that there were 27,000 cases in the last week in England alone, up from 14,000 the week before. The Minister of Health also announced that 415,000 H1N1 vaccinations shall take place on the week beginging 21 October, then 5,000,000 more vaccinations the week after. 20% of all hospitalized cases are now critical, up from 12% the week before. The government believes it can get 50,000,000 Britons vaccinated before Christmas.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20091015-712522.html |title=UK Swine Flu Cases Rise, Vaccines Available From Next Week - 15th October 2009 |date=2009-10-15 |publisher=Wall Street Journal |deadurl=yes |accessdate=2 August 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100106160208/http://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20091015-712522.html |archivedate=6 January 2010 |df= }}</ref>
====October 16==== {{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' An initial shortfall of swine flu vaccine is predicted shortly after the proportion of deaths attributed to pneumonia and influenza goes above the epidemic threshold<ref name="https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly">[https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/ CDC - Seasonal Influenza (Flu) - Weekly Report: Influenza Summary Update]. Cdc.gov</ref> in some states,<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/8311891.stm|work=BBC News|title=US swine flu vaccines 'delayed'|date=2009-10-17| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> with flu activity widespread in 41 states.<ref name="https://www.cdc.gov/H1N1FLU">[https://www.cdc.gov/H1N1FLU/ CDC 2009 H1N1 Flu]. Cdc.gov (2010-07-15)</ref> It is also announced that the number cases, hospitalizations and deaths are unprecedented for this time of year, with flu-like illnesses accounting for 6.1% of all doctor visits, itself an unusually high number.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/17/health/17flu.html?_r=1&hpw|work=The New York Times|title=Officials See a Shortage in Vaccine for Swine Flu|first=Denise|last=Grady|date=2009-10-17| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>

{{flagicon|Mongolia}} '''Mongolia''' First death confirmed.<ref>[http://mongolianviews.blogspot.com/2009/10/first-death-due-to-swine-flu-in.html Mongolian Views: First death due to swine flu in Mongolia]. Mongolianviews.blogspot.com (2009-10-23)</ref>

====November 30==== {{flagicon|USA}} '''United States''' The [[Center for Disease Control|CDC]] states that H1N1 may have peaked as the number of states reporting widespread influenza dropped from 43 the previous week to 32 this week. Furthermore, influenza-like illness now account for 4.3% of doctor visits, down from 8% four weeks ago (on average, influenza accounts for 2.5% of doctor visits). The proportion of deaths attributed to pneumonia and influenza continues to be higher than expected for this time of year, however. This proportion has remained elevated for eight weeks now.<ref name="ReferenceC">[https://www.cdc.gov/h1n1flu/update.htm CDC H1N1 Flu|Situation Update]. Cdc.gov</ref>

====December 5==== {{flagicon|US}} '''US''' CDC FluView Week 48: Widespread flu activity in 14 states, regional activity in 25. "The proportion of deaths attributed to pneumonia and influenza (P&I) was above the epidemic threshold for the tenth consecutive week. The proportion of outpatient visits for influenza-like illness (ILI) was 2.7% which is above the national baseline of 2.3%."<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/weeklyarchives2009-2010/weekly48.htm CDC - Seasonal Influenza (Flu) - Weekly Report: Influenza Summary Update]. Cdc.gov</ref>
====December 6==== {{flagicon|Gaza}} '''Gaza Strip''' First five cases are confirmed in the blockaded [[Gaza Strip]].<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE5B50YA20091206 | work=Reuters | title=H1N1 virus finally reaches blockaded Gaza Strip | date=2009-12-06| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{flagicon|Japan}} '''Japan''' 100 fatalities confirmed.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE5B50EO20091206 | work=Reuters | first=Tetsushi | last=Kajimoto | title=H1N1 deaths hit 100 in Japan: report | date=2009-12-06| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{flagicon|US}} '''US''' With one in six Americans infected, or 15% of the country, nearly 10,000 have died to date, including 1,100 children and 7,500 younger adults. More than 200,000 Americans had been hospitalized to date — roughly the same number who are so affected by the regular seasonal flu variant in an entire year. Furthermore, with 12 million additional doses of H1N1 vaccine being released this week, several states begin to distribute the vaccine to the general public.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE5AO3Z420091210 | work=Reuters | title=Swine flu has killed 10,000 Americans since April | date=2009-12-10| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
====December 7==== {{flagicon|North Korea}} '''North Korea''' First deaths are confirmed, according to newsletters released by the Seoul-based aid group Good Friends.<ref>[http://goodfriendsusa.blogspot.com/2009/12/north-korea-today-no-311no311-1-hot.html North Korea Today - Good Friends: North Korea Today No. 311/No.311-1 Hot Topics December 2009]. Goodfriendsusa.blogspot.com (2009-12-08)</ref><ref>[https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20091208/ap_on_re_as/as_koreas_swine_flu;_ylt=Ano4rtHUnNuIVB6qnxVoPoYBxg8F;_ylu=X3oDMTJxcnZudTlqBGFzc2V0A2FwLzIwMDkxMjA4L2FzX2tvcmVhc19zd2luZV9mbHUEcG9zAzMyBHNlYwN5bl9wYWdpbmF0ZV9zdW1tYXJ5X2xpc3QEc2xrA3Nrb3JlYW5wcmVzaQ-- <!-- |accessdate=December 9, 2009 --> ]{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
{{flagicon|US}} '''US''' A sophisticated [[Bayesian analysis]] of public health data from April to the end of June from New York City and Milwaukee<ref>[http://www.plosmedicine.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pmed.1000207 The Severity of Pandemic H1N1 Influenza in the United States, from April to July 2009: A Bayesian Analysis]. PLoS Medicine</ref> indicates that the pandemic's symptomatic case-fatality ratio has been far lower than the previous three pandemics of 1968, 1957, and 1918, making it to date the mildest pandemic on record.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/booster_shots/2009/12/swine-flu-may-be-mildest-pandemic-ever-researchers-say.html | work=Los Angeles Times | title=Swine flu may be mildest pandemic ever, researchers say | date=2009-12-08| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/12/07/AR2009120703162.html|work=The Washington Post|title=Flu pandemic could be mildest on record|first=Rob|last=Stein|date=2009-12-08| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
====December 9==== {{flagicon|Macao}} '''Macao''' First mutation confirmed, in the country's first H1N1 fatality.<ref>[http://english.cctv.com/program/cctvnews/20091209/103796.shtml A/H1N1 mutation reported in Macao CCTV-International]. English.cctv.com</ref>
====December 12==== {{flagicon|Afghanistan}} '''Afghanistan''' The 17th H1N1 fatality is reported.<ref>[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-12/12/content_12637268.htm A/H1N1 kills 17 in Afghanistan _English_Xinhua]. News.xinhuanet.com (2009-12-12)</ref>
{{flagicon|Gaza}} '''Gaza''' The eighth fatality is reported, that of a child with underlying kidney failure, within a week of the first H1N1 case in the Gaza Strip.<ref>[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-12/12/content_12637378.htm Palestinian child dies of A/H1N1 flu in Gaza _English_Xinhua]. News.xinhuanet.com (2009-12-12)</ref>
{{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' CDC FluView Week 49: Widespread influenza activity in 11 states, regional activity in twenty. "The proportion of deaths attributed to pneumonia and influenza (P&I) was above the epidemic threshold for the eleventh consecutive week... The proportion of outpatient visits for influenza-like illness (ILI) was 2.6% which is above the national baseline of 2.3%. Five of the 10 regions reported ILI at or above region-specific baseline levels."<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/weeklyarchives2009-2010/weekly49.htm CDC - Seasonal Influenza (Flu) - Weekly Report: Influenza Summary Update]. Cdc.gov</ref>
====December 13==== {{flagicon|Georgia}} '''Georgia''' First fatality confirmed, that of a 27-year-old man.<ref>[http://en.rian.ru/world/20091213/157217403.html Georgia reports first lethal case of swine flu|World|RIA Novosti]. En.rian.ru (2010-02-08)</ref>
{{flagicon|Qatar}} '''Qatar''' Mass vaccinations begin.<ref>[http://www.menafn.com/qn_news_story_s.asp?StoryId=1093288107 Qatar- Mass H1N1 vaccination begins today]. Menafn.com (2009-12-13)</ref>
====December 16==== {{flagicon|US}} '''US''' Roughly 100 million H1N1 vaccines<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/18/health/18flu.html?hpw|work=The New York Times|title=Assessment and Thanks as Flu Wave Ebbs in U.S.|date=2009-12-18|first=Donald G.|last=Mcneil Jr.|accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> become widely available to the general public in pharmacies in several American states as the supply increases and restrictions to high-risk groups are lifted.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE5BF28P20091216 | work=Reuters | title=Walgreen leads U.S. drugstores with H1N1 vaccine |date=2009-12-16| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20091216-714065.html |title=2nd UPDATE: Walgreen To Offer H1N1 Vaccine Nationwide By Year End |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091217024622/http://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20091216-714065.html |archivedate=2009-12-17 |accessdate=12 May 2013}}</ref>
====December 17==== {{flagicon|Thailand}} '''Thailand''' First confirmed case of H1N1 in a pig, in a case of reverse zoonosis in Saraburi Province. The pig recovered.<ref>[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-12/17/content_12661446.htm Thailand's pig infected with A/H1N1 but recovers: health official _English_Xinhua]. News.xinhuanet.com (2009-12-17)</ref>
====December 19==== {{flagicon|US}} '''US''' CDC FluView Week 50: The [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] reports that levels of influenza are declining steadily, with only seven states reporting widespread influenza activity and 18 reporting regional activity; furthermore, the proportion of deaths attributed to pneumonia and influenza (P&I) is below the epidemic threshold. The CDC also notes that almost all isolates of H1N1 remain sensitive to [[oseltamivir]].<ref name="https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly"/><ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/h1n1flu/updates/us/#totalcases CDC 2009 H1N1 Flu|2009 H1N1 U.S. Situation Update]. Cdc.gov</ref> "The proportion of outpatient visits for influenza-like illness (ILI) was 2.3% which is at the national baseline of 2.3%."<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/weeklyarchives2009-2010/weekly50.htm CDC - Seasonal Influenza (Flu) - Weekly Report: Influenza Summary Update]. Cdc.gov</ref>
====December 21==== {{flagicon|US}} '''US''' First case of canine zoonosis confirmed. The 13-year-old dog from New York state was believed to have contracted the virus from his owner.<ref>[http://www.petmd.com/dog/pet_lover/nws_dg_NYdog_h1n1 Dog in New York Diagnosed with Swine Flu]. PetMD (2009-12-22)</ref>
====December 23==== {{flagicon|US}} '''US''' H1N1 is discovered at two North Carolina pig farms, making it the 10th state to identify the virus in animals. The swine caught the disease from infected workers and recovered after becoming moderately ill.<ref>[http://www.newsobserver.com/news/local_state/story/254958.html H1N1 found at pig farms - Health/Science]. NewsObserver.com</ref>
{{flagicon|Argentina}} '''Argentina''' An Argentine study published in the [[New England Journal of Medicine]] shows that "Pediatric 2009 H1N1 influenza was associated with pediatric death rates that were 10 times the rates for seasonal influenza than in previous years,"<ref>[http://h1n1.nejm.org/?p=1390 Pediatric Hospitalizations Associated with 2009 Pandemic Influenza A (H1N1) in Argentina|H1N1 Influenza Center]. H1n1.nejm.org (2009-12-23)</ref> and that the elevated risk for pregnant women extends for as long as two weeks after they give birth.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE5BM49R20091223 | work=Reuters | title=Swine flu deadlier in children than seasonal flu | date=2009-12-23| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Libster |first1=R |last2=Bugna |first2=J |last3=Coviello |first3=S |last4=Hijano |first4=DR |last5=Dunaiewsky |first5=M |last6=Reynoso |first6=N |last7=Cavalieri |first7=ML |last8=Guglielmo |first8=MC |last9=Areso |first9=MS |title=Pediatric hospitalizations associated with 2009 pandemic influenza A (H1N1) in Argentina |journal=The New England Journal of Medicine |volume=362 |issue=1 |pages=45–55 |year=2010 |pmid=20032320 |doi=10.1056/NEJMoa0907673}}</ref>
====December 26==== {{flagicon|US}} '''US''' CDC FluView Week 51: Influenza activity decreases slightly, although the proportion of deaths attributed to P&I remained above the epidemic threshold. "Four states reported geographically widespread influenza activity, 13 states reported regional influenza activity, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and 19 states reported local influenza activity, Guam and 13 states reported sporadic influenza activity, and one state reported no influenza activity, the U.S. Virgin Islands did not report."<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/weeklyarchives2009-2010/weekly51.htm CDC - Seasonal Influenza (Flu) - Weekly Report: Influenza Summary Update]. Cdc.gov</ref>
====December 27====
{{flagicon|WHO}} '''WHO''' At least 12,220 deaths globally are formally confirmed. (By contrast, the WHO estimates that the seasonal flu kills from 250,000 to 300,000 people around the world each year.) Overall, the activity of the H1N1 pandemic has peaked.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE5BT35I20091230 | work=Reuters | title=At least 12,220 dead from H1N1 around world: WHO | date=2009-12-30| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{flagicon|Nepal}} '''Nepal''' First death confirmed, that of a woman who suffered major organ failure.<ref>[http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/Asia/Story/STIStory_471187.html Nepals 1st H1N1 death]. Straitstimes.com (2009-12-28)</ref>
====December 29==== {{flagicon|WHO}} '''WHO''' In Geneva Dr. [[Margaret Chan]], Director-General of the WHO, remarks in the context of the [[H5N1]] bird flu virus that "The fact that the long overdue influenza pandemic is so moderate in its impact is probably the best health news of the decade" but that "No, the world is not ready for a pandemic to be caused by H5N1." Given that H1N1 could still mutate, however, the WHO shall continue to monitor the pandemic for six months to a year. She also said that it would take at least two years before a true death total is established. (Approximately 11,500 people are believed to have died in more than 200 countries.)<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/8434273.stm |work=BBC News |title=Swine flu pandemic 'not yet over' |date=2009-12-29 |accessdate=2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100705171119/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/8434273.stm |archivedate=5 July 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
====December 30==== {{flagicon|US}} A study published in the NEJM finds that "household contacts less than 18 years of age were twice as susceptible to an acute respiratory illness as were those 19 to 50 years of age, whereas contacts older than 50 years were less susceptible".<ref>[http://h1n1.nejm.org/?p=1415 Household Transmission of 2009 Pandemic Influenza A (H1N1) Virus in the United States|H1N1 Influenza Center]. H1n1.nejm.org (2009-12-30)</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cauchemez|first1=S|last2=Donnelly|first2=CA|last3=Reed|first3=C|last4=Ghani|first4=AC|last5=Fraser|first5=C|last6=Kent|first6=CK|last7=Finelli|first7=L|last8=Ferguson|first8=NM|title=Household transmission of 2009 pandemic influenza A (H1N1) virus in the United States|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|volume=361|issue=27|pages=2619–27|year=2009|pmid=20042753|doi=10.1056/NEJMoa0905498|pmc=3840270}}</ref>
====December 31==== {{flagicon|US}}{{flagicon|UK}} A joint US-UK study shows that children are twice as likely as adults to catch H1N1.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/8434803.stm|work=BBC News|title=Swine flu 'more likely in young'|date=2009-12-31| accessdate= 2 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>

No influenza activity is reported in Nebraska. "One state reported geographically widespread influenza activity, 12 states reported regional influenza activity, Puerto Rico, the District of Columbia, and 17 states reported local influenza activity, the U.S. Virgin Islands, Guam, 19 states reported sporadic influenza activity, and one state reported no influenza activity."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/weeklyarchives2009-2010/weekly52.htm|title=CDC - Seasonal Influenza (Flu) - Weekly Report: Influenza Summary Update|website=www.cdc.gov}}</ref>
====January 8==== {{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' The CDC reports that only one state —Alabama— reports widespread influenza activity.<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/h1n1flu/updates/us/010810.htm CDC 2009 H1N1 Flu|2009 H1N1 U.S. Situation Update]. Cdc.gov</ref>

====January 20==== {{flagicon|Bermuda}} '''Bermuda''' First death confirmed.<ref>[https://archive.is/20120913082445/http://www.royalgazette.com/rg/Article/article.jsp?articleId=7da1a2b3003000f&sectionId=60 The Royal Gazette]. The Royal Gazette (2010-01-20)</ref>

{{flagicon|Nigeria}} '''Nigeria''' First death confirmed.<ref>[http://www.aol.in/news-story/nigeria-reports-first-swine-flurelated-death/755100 Nigeria reports first swine flu-related death - AOL India News]. Aol.in (2010-01-19) {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>

Cdc.gov</ref>

====March 26==== {{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' According to the CDC, only three states have reported regional influenza activity: Alabama, Georgia, and South Carolina.<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/h1n1flu/updates/us/032610.htm CDC 2009 H1N1 Flu|2009 H1N1 U.S. Situation Update]. Cdc.gov</ref>

====March 31==== {{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' The CDC [[Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report]] states that inoculation rates varied, with the highest rates in New England and the lowest in the South. (E.g., roughly 39% of the population of Rhode Island is immunized vis-à-vis 13% that of Mississippi.) Among children Georgia had the lowest vaccination rate, with 21%; the state currently has the highest level of H1N1 flu activity.<ref>[http://vaccinenewsdaily.com/news/212664-cdc-reports-states-h1n1-flu-inoculation-rates-vary-widely CDC reports states' H1N1 flu inoculation rates vary widely]. Vaccine News Daily (2010-03-31)</ref>
===April 2010===
====April 2==== {{flagicon|US}} '''US''' According to the CDC, only three states have reported regional influenza activity: Alabama, Georgia, and South Carolina.<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/h1n1flu/updates/us/040210.htm CDC 2009 H1N1 Flu|2009 H1N1 U.S. Situation Update]. Cdc.gov</ref>
{{flagicon|Cambodia}} '''Cambodia''' Mass vaccinations begin.<ref>[http://www1.voanews.com/khmer-english/news/a-40-2010-04-02-voa3-90235787.html?rss=cambodia 300,000 H1N1 Vaccinations Underway|News|Khmer-English]. .voanews.com (2010-04-02) {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
====April 9==== {{flagicon|US}} '''US''' According to the CDC, only three states have reported regional influenza activity: Alabama, Georgia, and South Carolina.<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/h1n1flu/updates/us/040910.htm CDC 2009 H1N1 Flu|2009 H1N1 U.S. Situation Update]. Cdc.gov</ref>
====April 12==== {{flagicon|Guinea}} '''Guinea''' First case confirmed.<ref>[http://www.lejourguinee.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=2623&Itemid=1 Lejourguinee-Medium Guinéen de l'actualité instantanée]. Lejourguinee.com {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100415135730/http://www.lejourguinee.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=2623&Itemid=1 |date=April 15, 2010 }}</ref>
====April 14==== {{flagicon|WHO}} '''WHO''' An external panel advises against winding down the pandemic alert level until experts have tracked the southern hemisphere's traditional autumn and winter flu season. Accusations of undue influence from the pharmaceutical industry were also addressed.<ref>[http://globalhealth.kff.org/Daily-Reports/2010/April/15/GH-041410-Swine-Flu-Probe.aspx First Meeting Of WHO H1N1 Response Probe Concludes - Kaiser Global Health]. Globalhealth.kff.org (2010-04-15)</ref>
====April 17==== {{flagicon|US}} '''US''' According to the CDC, no states have reported either widespread or regional influenza activity, and four have reported local activity: Hawaii, Alabama, Georgia, and South Carolina.<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/h1n1flu/updates/us/index.htm CDC 2009 H1N1 Flu|2009 H1N1 U.S. Situation Update]. Cdc.gov</ref>
====April 19==== {{flagicon|WHO}} '''WHO''' Director-General Dr. [[Margaret Chan]] states that "It is still premature and too early for us to say we have come to an end of the pandemic influenza worldwide. It would be prudent and appropriate... to continue to monitor the evolution of this pandemic for the next six to 12 months," i.e. possibly into 2011. She also remarked that although the United States, Britain and Canada have passed through a second wave of H1N1, outbreaks in India, Egypt and elsewhere are intensifying, and reiterates that countries remain ill-prepared for a [[H5N1|bird flu]] (H5N1) pandemic. More than 200 countries have now been affected by H1N1 with almost 12,000 confirmed deaths worldwide, although the vast majority of those infected recovered without special treatment.<ref>[http://vaccinenewsdaily.com/news/212774-who-warns-h1n1-to-continue-through-2011 WHO warns H1N1 to continue through 2011]. Vaccine News Daily (2010-04-20)</ref>
====April 26==== {{flagicon|Philippines}} '''Philippines''' Mass vaccinations begin.<ref>[http://www.gmanews.tv/story/189275/doh-1st-recipient-to-get-shot-of-ah1n1vaccine-monday DOH: 1st recipient to get shot of A(H1N1)vaccine Monday - Nation - GMANews.TV - Official Website of GMA News and Public Affairs - Latest Philippine News]. GMANews.TV</ref>
===May 2010===
====May 15==== {{flagicon|US}} '''US''' Only one state -Hawaii- reports local flu activity, and 28 states report no flu activity.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}}
====May 16==== {{flagicon|WHO}} '''WHO''' Director-General Dr. [[Margaret Chan]] states at the U.N.'s [[World Health Assembly]] that "We are just plain lucky ... This has been the case with the A/ H1N1 influenza pandemic... The virus did not mutate to a more lethal form. Cases of resistance to oseltamivir remained few and isolated. The vaccine closely matched circulating viruses and showed an excellent safety record," Chan said. "Emergency wards and intensive care units were often strained, few health systems were overwhelmed ... Schools closed, but borders remained open, and disruptions to travel and trade were far less severe than feared," she told delegates from the agency's 193 member states. "Had things gone wrong in any of these areas, we would have a very different agenda before us today," she added."<ref name=xinhuanet2010>{{cite news |title=WHO chief says world "lucky" to have mild pandemic influenza |author=<!--no byline--> |agency=[[Xinhua News Agency]] |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-05/18/c_13299715.htm |work=[[Xinhuanet]] |date=18 May 2010 |accessdate=27 June 2013 }}</ref>
===August 2010===
====August 6==== {{flagicon|US}} '''US''' Researchers discover the mutation which had enabled the pandemic.<ref name=meddaily2010>{{cite news |title=Gene mutation caused 2009 H1N1 virus spread |author=<!-- no byline --> |url=http://www.medicaldaily.com/news/20100806/944/gene-mutation-caused-2009-h1n1-virus-spread.htm |publisher=Medical Daily<!-- no article as of June 2013 --> |date=6 August 2010 |accessdate=27 June 2013 }}</ref><ref name=devitt2011>{{cite web|url=http://www.vetmed.wisc.edu/articles/0/5/1170 |title=H1N1 Flu Virus Used New Biochemical Trick to Cause Pandemic |last1=Devitt |first1=Terry |year=2011<!-- from page copyright --> |website=School of Veterinary Medicine |publisher=[[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] |accessdate=27 June 2013 |archivedate=9 August 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110809013010/http://www.vetmed.wisc.edu/articles/0/5/1170/ |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
====August 10==== {{flagicon|WHO}} [[WHO Director-General|'''WHO''' Director-General]] [[Margaret Chan]] officially declares the H1N1 pandemic over as countries are now seeing a mix of H1N1, H3N2, and B viruses, with some populaces displaying community-level immunity to H1N1 of 20% to 40%.<ref name=neale2010>{{cite news |title=WHO Declares End to H1N1 Pandemic |last=Neale |first=Todd |date=10 August 2010 |work=www.medpagetoday.com |url=http://www.medpagetoday.com/InfectiousDisease/SwineFlu/21603 }}</ref> Nevertheless, Angus Nicoll<!-- no bio article as of June 2013 --> of the [[European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control]] urged health officials worldwide to "prepare for a new type of seasonal flu to appear in the near future that will combine elements of the pandemic A(H1N1) strain, and older A(H3N2) strain and several lesser strains".<ref name=jordans2010>{{cite news |title=WHO says swine flu pandemic is over |last=Jordans |first=Frank |publisher=[[Yahoo! News]] |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20100810/ap_on_he_me/un_med_who_swine_flu |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=10 August 2012 |accessdate=27 June 2013 |archivedate=15 August 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100815222240/https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20100810/ap_on_he_me/un_med_who_swine_flu }}</ref> "Pandemics are unpredictable and prone to deliver surprises," Director-General Chan noted.<ref name=jordans2010/>
==Summary== {{Main article|2009 flu pandemic timeline summary}}
==See also== *[[2009 flu deaths by region]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{2009 swine flu}}

revision.text:
'''American College of Occupational and Environmental Medicine''' is a United States-based [[professional society]] which promotes health care professionals in the field of [[occupational safety and health]].
==Projects== In the early 1990s the ACOEM expressed concern about a shortage of physicians in its field.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.7326/0003-4819-113-12-983| title = Physician Shortage in Occupational and Environmental Medicine| journal = Annals of Internal Medicine| volume = 113| issue = 12| pages = 983–6| year = 1990| last1 = Castorina | first1 = J. S.| pmid=2240921}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1056/NEJM199109263251305| title = Occupational and Environmental Medicine| journal = New England Journal of Medicine| volume = 325| issue = 13| pages = 924–927| year = 1991| last1 = Rosenstock | first1 = L. | last2 = Rest | first2 = K. M. | last3 = Benson | first3 = J. A. | last4 = Cannella | first4 = J. M. | last5 = Cohen | first5 = J. | last6 = Cullen | first6 = M. R. | last7 = Davidoff | first7 = F. | last8 = Landrigan | first8 = P. J. | last9 = Reynolds | first9 = R. C. | last10 = Clever | first10 = L. H. | last11 = Ellis | first11 = G. B. | last12 = Goldstein | first12 = B. D. }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{official website|http://www.acoem.org/}} *''[http://journals.lww.com/joem/Pages/default.aspx Journal of Occupational and Environmental Medicine]'', which is published by the organization *[https://web.archive.org/web/20140222152259/http://www.guideline.gov/browse/by-organization.aspx?orgid=446 guidelines published by ACOEM] as archived by the [[Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality]]
[[Category:Medical associations based in the United States]] [[Category:Occupational safety and health]] [[Category:Environmental social science]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in Illinois]]

{{Unreferenced stub|auto=yes|date=December 2009}} '''Angak''' is a [[Hopi]] [[kachina]] spirit, represented by spirit dancers and a corresponding kachina doll figure, known to non-hopis as ''Longhair''.
==Spirit character== Angak represents a healing and protective male figure.
==Dance representation== The dance of this figure is slow.
==Figure representation== The figure will have waist length black hair and a black beard to mid chest, and when represented as a carving will usually be taller than other kachinas by the same artist. The figure wears a full length white cape, showing only his right hand, which contains an evergreen bough, representative of his home in the sacred [[San Francisco Peaks]]. On the cape are symbols for rainclouds.
==Headdress== The forward part of the headdress over the brow consists of yellow feathers, while the rear part contains a long pendant of feathers terminating in a raincloud symbol. (Feathers in the doll are carved.)
[[Category:Hopi mythology]] [[Category:Health deities]]
{{NorthAm-myth-stub}}
